div1.p: THE COQUETTE; OR, THE MISTAKES of the HEART.
THE COQUETTE; OR, THE MISTAKES of the HEART: A COMEDY. As performed at the THEATRES-ROYAL IN YORK and HULL.

div1.head: TO Mrs. NEWTON, OF KING's-BROMLEY, STAFFORDSHIRE.
div1.p: WITH the greatest respect, I beg leave to lay the following scenes at your feet—My sole aim in writing them, was to blend Instruction with Amusement.
TRULY sensible that Example operates much more powerfully than Precept, forgive my vanity in pointing out so perfect a character as your's for imitation.
WHERE Youth, Beauty, and Virtue unite to—Your delicacy has snatched the pen from my unwilling hand—I must obey—Suffer me only to add, that I am, MADAM,

closer.signed: With the greatest truth, Your most obedient Very humble servant, The AUTHOR.

div1.p: THE moment that a Reader takes up a Book with a Design to peruse it, he naturally wishes for all the Information possible, relative to the Writer and Writing of it—
WILLING, in every reasonable Degree, to satisfy the Curiosity of my good Friends and Purchasers, I shall candidly answer their following Questions:
Pray, who is the Author of this Comedy?

p.hi: A man in Obscurity, unnoticed, and content to remain so.

div1.p: Has it ever been performed in London?
Was it ever offered to the Managers of either Theatre there?

p.hi: Because the Author was truly sensible that it had not Merit sufficient to recommend it to their Notice.

div1.p: What are his Motives for publishing it now?

p.hi: An odd Question—He is afraid not—But, good bye, Read on and judge for yourself.

div1.head: THE COQUETTE; OR, THE MISTAKES of the HEART.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: SO, Sedley, you really have been three weeks without seeing Miss Bloomer?

sp.speaker: Sedl.
sp.p: True, I assure you, Woodford, and intend, if my resolution holds, never to see her again.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: But I understood every thing was settled between you both, and that nothing remain'd but to name the happy day.

sp.speaker: Sedl.
sp.p: Prithee, Woodford, no more.—It adds to my uneasiness to hear her mention'd.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: Why so?

sp.speaker: Sedl.
sp.p: Because I find, this too susceptible heart of mine cannot so readily erase the impressions her youth, beauty, and innocence have made upon it.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: Indeed! But what reason can you have for wishing it?

sp.speaker: Sedl.
sp.p: The greatest in the world, Woodford.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: I cannot think so,—explain, or I shall certainly imagine you whimsical and capricious.

sp.speaker: Sedl.
sp.p:
When I first paid my addresses to Miss Bloomer, such were the beauties of her mind as well
as person, that I fancied I had found one, all perfect as the first, before she fell.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: Then were you in an Adamitical paradise.

sp.speaker: Sedl.
sp.p: A fool's one, rather,—she received me with such a flattering distinction that I thought myself the happiest of mortals, when unluckily, her guardian's dying put her into the immediate possession of a large fortune.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: Now I should have thought that the luckiest circumstance that cou'd have happen'd.

sp.speaker: Sedl.
sp.p: Quite the contrary,—thus freed from restraint, at the age of eighteen, she emerged into all the fashionable follies of the great world, without a real friend to advise, or direct her.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: Why did not you undertake that office?

sp.speaker: Sedl.
sp.p: I did, but soon found it was an ungrateful one—so fine a girl, independent of interested motives, cou'd not fail of attracting a crowd of admirers; and—

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: You, naturally grew jealous.

sp.speaker: Sedl.
sp.p: Jealous! My heart was torn in pieces.—'Twas then I discover'd a levity of temper, a thoughtlessness, a love of pleasure, that destroy'd my hopes.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: Psha! trifles.—Foibles like these are as specks upon the sun.

sp.speaker: Sedl.
sp.p: Ay, but in time they threaten a total eclipse.—No character, however contemptible, but was encouraged as a lover.—No scene of gaiety, however censurable, but was pursued with avidity.—A thousand instances did I patiently bear with, in hopes of amendment.—Oft in the gentlest terms, did I convey advice, and represent the hazards she ran; as oft was I forbad her presence.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! upon my word, you took an excellent method of rendering yourself agreeable to a girl of her age and spirit.

sp.speaker: Sedl.
sp.p:
But when I intended that girl as a partner for life, cou'd you blame my cautious conduct? No,
Woodford; though never man was more sensible of beauty's charms than I, yet unless those charms are adorned with virtue, they make not half the impression.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: That's a little romantic; but pray go on.

sp.speaker: Sedl.
sp.p: Many times did I rescue her from the most imminent dangers which her indiscretions plunged her into, yet still she persevered.—At length,—

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: Hold, who comes here?

sp.speaker: Sedl.
sp.p: Oh, 'tis Monsieur Finesse,—one of my rivals,—a fellow, whose impudence can only be equall'd by his ignorance.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Ah, gentlement!—Votre tres humble serviteur!—I be most glad to see you both,—Monsieur Sedley, I beg a to speak von word or two wid you.

sp.speaker: Sedl.
sp.p: Any thing particular, Finesse?

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Oh, oui, ver particular—for your own ear.

sp.speaker: Sedl.
sp.p: You may speak out before Woodford, I have just been acquainting him with the whole affair.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Qu' avez vous fair?—Ma foy, dat be wrong done.—You shou'd say noting to hurt de fine Lady's reputation.

sp.speaker: Sedl.
sp.p: He is my particular friend, and I can answer for his discretion.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Parbleu! particular friend sometime do de mosht mischief.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: That will not be the case with me, I promise you.

sp.speaker: Sedl.
sp.p: Come, what news of Miss Bloomer?

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Ah, pauvre Lady! she had de grand escape yesterday.

sp.speaker: Sedl.
sp.p: Escape? how?

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Why, she be taking de innocent diversion at Vauxhall, wid de bon companie, as she suppose, and engage in de partie wid tree gentlemen, and deux ladie, to be entertain in a boat on de Thames.

sp.speaker: Sedl.
sp.p: In a boat on the Thames?—Well!—Go on.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Dey be all stranger to her, but vat of dat? She not tink any harm.—So dey row, row along, have de musique, sing de petite chanson, and be all so merry and gay, till dey land at de Cousin, as dey call her, but begar she be—Vat you call Fille de joie?

sp.speaker: Sedl.
sp.p: Woman of the town.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Oui,—she be woman of de town,—den Miss Bloomer find her mistake, and vant to return home again.—Dey say, no, no, and grow hardis,—at last, when she be almost excedée, etrois gentlemen by accident hear her cries, and tout à fait, rescue her.

sp.speaker: Sedl.
sp.p: Wou'd I had been there!—Villains!

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Oh, oui!—Villains indeed.

sp.speaker: Sedl.
sp.p: You see, Woodford, there's another instance of her conduct.—Do you think it possible for me to be happy with such a woman?

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: I tell you, man, you are too delicate.—Tho' appearances are against her, yet, I dare affirm, that these are all mistakes of the heart, which in time her better judgment will rectify.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: True, dey be all in de heart,—all vivacité, noting else.—I must find some oder opportunity, when I shall have him to himself. (aside) Well, Monsieur Sedley, I vill bid you de good morn,—I am going to visit de Lady, I shall hear someting more dere, and den I vill call on you at home, in private.—Gentlemen, sans compliment, I have de honneur to be your very humble servant.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: Hearky', Sedley, do you build anything upon this fellow's intelligence?—A wretch! that's an outcast, and disgrace to his nation.

sp.speaker: Sedl.
sp.p: Yet this very outcast, as he really is, does she treat in the most encouraging manner; and, without the least enquiry into his fortune or character, admit amongst the number of her admirers.—But let us change the subject.—So then it seems your Uncle has civilly dismiss'd you his house?

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: Not so civilly, I assure you.

sp.speaker: Sedl.
sp.p: Don't you think you deserved it? Captain Helm, you know, has spent the greater part of his life in ploughing the tempestuous ocean, and tho' possest of an excellent heart, has not the least idea of the refined sentiments inspired by a liberal education.—You were certain that your whole dependance was upon him, yet refus'd flattering the harmless foibles which peculiarly mark his character.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: You mistake me, Sedley, I often did, till this last affair.—But, when he commenc'd my rival, my happiness was too much concern'd to trifle any longer.

sp.speaker: Sedl.
sp.p: Well, and has he declar'd his passion?

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: No, but as a preparatory step, he has given Lady Younglove (who is just return'd to town with her daughter) to understand, that for the future, she must not encourage my pretensions, as I have nothing to expect from him.

sp.speaker: Sedl.
sp.p: So! your hopes are all over in that quarter?

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: Entirely! I called yesterday, to welcome my dear girl, my beauteous Flora, to London, and was refused admittance.

sp.speaker: Sedl.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: True, and I am now reduced to such distress, that, unless you can assist me with your advice, and—

sp.speaker: Sedl.
sp.p: Here's my hand,—Depend upon my utmost, I feel too much myself, tho' from a different cause, not to compassionate you.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: I expected no less from your generous friendship, but how shall we act?—What can I do?

sp.speaker: Sedl.
sp.p: Upon my word, I don't know.—I own yours is a critical case.—But, we must not despair,—I believe as matters stand, we had best work by stratagem. Luckily, I stand high in the estimation of your Uncle, as well as Lady Younglove.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: You'll find him inexorable, and her—

sp.speaker: Sedl.
sp.p: Not proof against flattery,—all mankind have their weak side, Woodford, and much may be done by taking a proper advantage of their follies.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: I wish you may not be mistaken in the present case.

sp.speaker: Sedl.
sp.p: Never fear.—Let me see, (Panses) No, that won't do.—Stay, I believe I have it.—Suppose, I attack Lady Younglove myself, and persuade her, that I am dying for love of her.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: No, no, that's impossible,—'twould be too ridiculous.

sp.speaker: Sedl.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! I'll lay my life there's nothing easier.—Attack Widows by storm, and they can't resist you.—Besides, her time grows short, and as she was in such a violent hurry to get a second husband, there's all the reason in the world to imagine her still more impatient for a third.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: But what end do you propose by this scheme?

sp.speaker: Sedl.
sp.p: To serve you, but in what manner I have not yet determined.—Come, let's home to my house and consider farther.—Nay, nay, no excuses.—I see you are unfit to be left to yourself.—And the heart which does not feel the distress of a friend, is not worthy of existence.

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.p: Ha! ha!—And so, Monsieur Sedley believe all de Mensonge, all de story you tell him of my Lady.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Oui, he tink it all verité.

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.p: Bon!—And I so speak in your praise, dat she love you more dan all her oder admirers.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Brave, ma petite mignonne!—And, she be assurée, dat I be von man of grand qualite?

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.p: Sans doubt!—she no suspect any ting—But, you remember—If I help you to marry de Lady, I am to have de five hundred pound.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Oh!—Faites fond sur moi—Depend upon me.

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.p: Vera well—Je suis content!—I am satisfied,—She be now alone, stay you dere, and I vil say you are waiting for her.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Allons, Mademoiselle.—Begar! I vil put de von little sheat upon you too, for all dat.—Love own country vera well, but love own self mush better.

sp.speaker: Span.
sp.p: Ha! my dear Monsieur Finesse—I am extravagantly glad to see you.—I wish he was at the Devil with all my heart.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: You make me quite happy.—If your neck was broke.

sp.speaker: Span.
sp.p: What, I find you still dance attendance at Miss Bloomer's levee.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Il est vrai, Monsieur Ogle—It is true,—When a young Lady like Miss Bloomer distinguish de gentilhomme, de gentilhomme do all in his power to return de compliment.

sp.speaker: Span.
sp.p: You are right, Monsieur,—Just my case to a hair.—If a foolish girl takes it into her head, to fall desperately in love with me,—tho' upon my soul, I can't see for what—Can I be so barbarous as to slight her?—Oh, no, 'tis not in my nature to be so inhuman. [Miss Bloomer sings without.] Hark!—Here she comes, and as lively as ever.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Gentlemen, your most obedient,—Hey day! Only you two!—Why I am quite deserted this morning.—Oh, Mr. Spangle! what not drowned yet?—Psha! you are not half the despairing lover you ought to be.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Oh, fie for shame, Monsieur Spangle, not drown yourself to please de Lady.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!—I dare say, Monsieur Finesse, you'd readily oblige me with such a proof of your gallantry, and respect.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Oh, madam, I beg to be excuse—De hang, and de drown'd be so barbare, so truly Englis, dat it shock a me quite—No, rader let me live to adore you, ma belle ange.

sp.speaker: Span.
sp.p: Then is there no possibility of inspiring that obdurate bosom of yours?

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Oh! I am in love!

sp.speaker: Span.
sp.p: Indeed!

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Yes, violently, to distraction.

sp.speaker: Span.
sp.p: And may I ask, who is the happy object of your passion?

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: The monkey you gave me—He is so much the image of yourself, that I have doted on him this week past.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! De monkey—Ha! ha! ha! le drole, serviteur, Monsieur Monkey.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: I assure you I intend to dress the dear creature up in a fashionable suit, have him frizz'd, powder'd, and painted alamode, and have not the least doubt but he'll acquit himself as well as most of the fine gentlemen about town.

sp.speaker: Span.
sp.p: You know the power you have over me, and love to tyrannize.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Poor gentleman!—how pathetically that was spoken! Pray go on.

sp.speaker: Span.
sp.p: I assure you, madam, little as you may think of—

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: That pretty, delicate, enamell'd face of yours; yet, it has made many a Lady's heart go pit-a-pat.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Admirable!—Ha! ha! ha!—Ah! pauvre diable, ha! ha!

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: As for Monsieur Finesse here, there is not the least fear of the weather's injuring his complexion.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: No, madam, mine be de true bronze.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p:
Well, gentlemen, I suppose you are both come upon the old subject—To shew how impartial
partial I am, both shall have fair play, and each declare his passion in turn. You, Mr. Spangle, being my humble servant the longest, shall begin first.—Come, make haste, you have no time to lose—I expect twenty more, every moment, on the same errand.

sp.speaker: Span.
sp.p: Hearky', you soft bewitching little gypsy.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Bravo! go on.

sp.speaker: Span.
sp.p: Do you think I am always to be treated in this unmerciful manner?

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.l: With mercy treat your humble slave,
And as your you're beautiful be brave.

sp.speaker: Span.
sp.p: Curse catch me! if I am not reveng'd on you for this cruelty.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: What, you'll break my chain?—Do, if you can—If my glass is to be believ'd, that's out of your power.—Well, since I find you have nothing more to say, now, to you—"Tho' last not least in my esteem."

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Den, madam, sans compliment, ou flatterie, you be de sweetest and most lovely creature I ever saw—And if I be so happy as to—

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Have it in your power to make me unhappy—

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: O, permettez moi, madam, you not hear me out.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Mrs. Fashion, your Ladyship's milliner, to wait on you.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Shew her up.—I am very sorry, gentlemen, to be deprived of the pleasure of your company, but business you know—

sp.speaker: Span.
sp.p: O, dear ma'am, no excuse—

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: I shall be glad to see you again, this afternoon.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Je m'en vais, madam, I shall be here when you no tink.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Hold, come back—I've a thought which may be of infinite service to you and me.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Pray, madam,—Que dites vous? Vat you say?

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Why, as you are both rivals, and men of such undoubted courage, what think you of a rencontre to-morrow morning?

sp.speaker: Span.
sp.p: O, dear ma'am, we are infinitely oblig'd to you.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Oui, too much oblige, indeed, madam.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: I wou'd not propose this to every hotheaded spark, but I have such a reliance upon your prudence and discretion, that I am not the least apprehensive of ill consequences.

sp.speaker: Span.
sp.p: You pay us a great compliment, really, madam.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: No more than you deserve,—By this, you'll acquire a reputation in the world, and add to my fame.—Go, go, and let me hear that you have done something to be talk'd of before I see you again.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Madam, I shall have de glory of obeying your commands.—Monsieur Spangle, since noting else will satisfy de lady, I beg you to witdraw, and let me have de honneur to cut your troat a la Françoise.

sp.speaker: Span.
sp.p: O, I'll withdraw with all my heart.—But, the Devil fetch me, if I have my throat cut, a la Françoise, or a la Anglois.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! thus do I sport with fools.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Well, Mrs. Fashion, sure something very particular brings you here.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fash.
sp.p: Very particular indeed, your Ladyship,—And yet, it is not particular to you neither, for, heaven bless you! it happens every day.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Well, what is it?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fash.
sp.p: Ah, that sweet sace!—No wonder it turns every body's brain.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: What is all this about?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fash.
sp.p: I assure you, I have so much work in hand, that I could hardly spare the time to—

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: I wish you would waste a little less of it now.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fash.
sp.p: Some of my best customers too.—I shall be oblig'd to sit up all night.—But poor gentleman, he is in such a bitter taking—

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: What gentleman?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fash.
sp.p: Ah! that sweet shape and air.—Well, if it be your lot to come together, you'll make a lovely couple.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Was ever any thing so provoking!—I protest, I shall be quite angry, if you keep me any longer in suspence.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fash.
sp.p: Angry! no, no, that face of yours was never made for frowning.—What say you to a new admirer, now?

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Psha! was this the mighty matter,—I don't want admirers, I promise you.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fash.
sp.p: No, by my faith, don't you, but this is one out of the common road.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Then, he had better turn into the common road again, or he may chance to go astray.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fash.
sp.p: Ah! you are always witty.—Oh, he is one of the cleverest, properest, best-bred gentlemen,—I'm sure he brings tears into my eyes, to hear all the fine things he says of you.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: You are very tender, indeed, Mrs. Fashion.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fash.
sp.p: As a chicken.—And then for quality, he tops them all.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Does he?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fash.
sp.p:
Oh, yes, Miss—You must know that his father's a Lord, he is the eldest son, but upon some little disagreement—A love affair—A Lady of
vast fortune his father wanted him to marry.—He took lodgings in my house, in order to be private, till matters are made up.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Then he is your lodger at present?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fash.
sp.p: And the best lodger I ever had—Money is no more to him than pins are to me.—Then for company, my house is hardly ever empty of Lords, Dukes, and Baronets.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Oh! he lives quite private, I find.—But, pray, what may be the name of this extraordinary person?

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fash.
sp.p: Why that's a secret—But between ourselves, I have found out from his servants, that he is the young Lord Flamwell.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Flamwell!—I never heard of the name before—But that's no wonder, for of late, nobility spring up like mushrooms.—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fash.
sp.p: He has seen you at some of the public places, and has been dying for you ever since.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: So, you are come Embassadress from him?

sp.speaker: Mrs Fash.
sp.p: Me, Miss!—Lord, what could put such a thing into your head?—He does not even know that I ever saw you—And yet, he is in such distress, that if you would condescend to come to my house this afternoon—

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: To your house?—Surely, Mrs. Fashion, you don't imagine, that—

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fash.
sp.p: Nay, only for a quarter of an hour, or so, by way of amusement.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: I thank you, but I don't want amusement.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fash.
sp.p: But, I have some of newest fashions come over from Paris—Not a creature in London has seen them, but myself—O, they'd become your Ladyship admirably—So elegant, so pretty—If you chuse, you may have the honour of leading the taste for the next three months.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: My dear Mrs. Fashion, you are very good.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fash.
sp.p: Ay, I thought I shou'd please you.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Then, I'll order my chair, and give you a call before dinner.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fash.
sp.p: I never saw any thing in my life so becoming.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Be sure, you don't let them be seen by any body before I come.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fash.
sp.p: Seen! no, not if a Dutchess was to bribe me.—Then, I'll expect your Ladyship.—Lord, what time I have spent, prattle, prattle, never think, and yet, so much work!—Hurry, hurry, not a minute to lose—Your Ladyship's most obedient, humble servant.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: This intelligence has given me new spirits—I protest, I began to be apprehensive that my charms were on the fade—A whole week passed, and not one new admirer.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: My dear Belgrove, you are come most opportunely—Do you know, that since I saw you last, I have made a fresh conquest?

sp.speaker: Miss Belg.
sp.p: I don't find any thing so surprizing in that.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Why no, that's true, but I have now rose a step higher, and captivated a Lord.

sp.speaker: Miss Belg.
sp.p: Lord, or commoner, I suppose he'll share the same fate with the rest.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Certainly, my dear, you would not have me be unjust.

sp.speaker: Miss Belg.
sp.p: No, really, I would not, therefore entirely disapprove of your making such fools of them.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: You mistake, child, the generality of them were fools ready made to my hand.

sp.speaker: Miss Belg.
sp.p: Some of them might be so, but I don't find you are in the least more favourable to men of sense.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Oh! I hate your sensible men, and take a particular pleasure in tormenting them.

sp.speaker: Miss Belg.
sp.p: That's very extraordinary.—But why so?

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Because it adds more to my reputation, to lead in chains one of those wise Lords of the creation, who has sense enough to know I use him ill, yet not power sufficient to break his fetters, than a thousand of those mincing, whiffling, trifling, good-for-nothing, pretty, Master Jessamys.

sp.speaker: Miss Belg.
sp.p: Well! tho' I shall never approve of your scheme, I almost wish for your spirits.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Spirits, my dear!—Lord, what should put me out of spirits?—Time enough for me to pine and languish, when the Hey-day of my charms are over—Mine, I'm afraid, will be but a short reign, so am determin'd to make the most of it.

sp.speaker: Miss Belg.
sp.p: Then I find you do intend to marry.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Yes, yes, some time or other.—. It wou'd mortify me prodigiously, to die an old maid.—No, no, I assure you, I have not the least ambition to lead apes, no more than I have at present to be led by one myself.—I wou'd only play with the male creatures, as a skilful angler does with his fish.—Amuse myself the sportive summer's day, bait my hook well for gudgeons, see the pretty innocents, nibble, nibble, nibble, as fast as I could cast in—Draw them out when I pleased—Stroke the delicate things, and then throw them in again—till evening sun having disagreeably lengthen'd my shadow, pick out the hero of the stream, and retire to my rustic cottage, content with the pleasures of the day.

sp.speaker: Miss Belg.
sp.p: But, pray, in the midst of this round of amusements, do you never feel a pang for the loss of Sedley?

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: If I really thought I had lost him for ever, I should be heartily mortified.

sp.speaker: Miss Belg.
sp.p: Don't you think it begins to look like it?

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Why, I am a little alarmed,—for to confess the truth sincerely, which in those cases I very seldom do—Of all the men that ever address'd me, he is the only one who has made an imprestion on my heart.

sp.speaker: Miss Belg.
sp.p: Why did not you use him better?

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: 'Tis not in my nature to be serious long together, therefore why should he expect it?

sp.speaker: Miss Belg.
sp.p: Consider the many obligations you are under to him.—The many dangers he rescued you from, which your innocent levity exposed you to.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: That's true; but then he should not have taken so ungenerous an advantage of them, as to tell me, that I did wrong, and prescribe rules for my future conduct.

sp.speaker: Miss Belg.
sp.p: Were not those rules for your good?

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Yes, but we are not always dispos'd to relish advice.

sp.speaker: Miss Belg.
sp.p: I really think, if you lose him, you'll never meet with such another.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: If I am disappointed of him, I shall never have any other, that's past a doubt—And as a proof, were he now to return, I would frankly own, that, though I am innocent, even in intention of acting wrong, yet, my thoughtlessness, many times, leads me into great errors, which nothing but the sincerity of my heart can excuse.

sp.speaker: Miss Belg.
sp.p: 'Tis great pity you did not make this declaration before.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Psha! he must take me, as he finds me.—Can he be so unconscionable as to expect, that I should draw up my head, hold down my eyes, put my hands together, drop him a low curtesy, and say,—I have been a naughty girl to be sure, but, pray forgive me this time, and indeed, and double deed, I'll do so no more?

sp.speaker: Miss Belg.
sp.p:
No, but he might reasonably expect, that you'd dismiss your numerous train of followers;
—and, as you have often sacrificed men of worth at the shrine of folly, so in return, to make a general oblation—Offer up a hecatomb of fools, at the altar of discretion.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Do I bid the creatures follow me?

sp.speaker: Miss Belg.
sp.p: Nor don't you encourage them, when they do?

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Ay, that is, because I hate ill-nature.

sp.speaker: Miss Belg.
sp.p: But are not you afraid your reputation should suffer?

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Oh, my dear, not in the least—Every thing we do becomes us,—Our very frailties are pleasing.

sp.speaker: Miss Belg.
sp.p: Consider, the—

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Positively, I won't consider about the matter—So, come along, and always remember these never-failing lines—
sp.l: If to her share, some female errors fall,
Look on her face, and you'll forget them all.

div3.head: SCENE, CAPTAIN HELM'S.
div3.stage: CAPTAIN HELM discover'd lying on a Couch, SWAB waiting.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: SWAB!

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: Here, your Honour.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: What sort of weather abroad?

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: A little hazey, your Honour; the wind S. S-E.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: D'ye think you cou'd take me under convoy as far as Lady Younglove's?

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: I warrant I'll tow you along, if so be as how you'll keep above water.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Say you so?—Then on with your best jacket and trowsers, and help me to rig myself out.
Ha! Sedley!—What chear, boy?—How goes it?

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Very well, I thank you, Captain.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Give me your hand—here, Swab, help to heave me up—so, so—now, turn out, and keep a strict watch.

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: If Bet Mainsail, my mess-mate's widow, hails me again, what answer shall I give her?

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Stow her hold well with right Nantz—Give her five guineas to buy new rigging, and tell her, if she'll hoist the sign of Admiral Boseawen on Portsmouth Common, I'll take care to keep her off a lee shore.

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: Bless your Honour's glory!—She shall have as much of the good creature as she can carry;—and, snatch my bowlings, if I don't tip her half a piece myself, for old acquaintance sake.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: You see I am laid upon the stocks a little, but no matter for that—Tho' my out-works are something damaged, yet my inside is heart of oak.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: I am glad to hear it—Presuming, Captain, on the regard you always profest for me, I am now come to intercede in behalf of your nephew.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Avast, avast, tack about, and pay away no more of that cable—My nephew, d'ye see, is a lazy land-lubber—If he had taken my advice, I would have made a man of him, and taught him to hand, reef, and steer, with e'er a seaman in the navy.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: These are accomplishments, Captain, not suitable to every man's taste and genius.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Then their taste is not worth a rope's end—I myself, tho' a younger brother, made my own fortune while his father was squandering away his—I was twice round the globe, before I was forty—In every birth, from cabbin-boy, up to Captain of the Terrible—And now, having sufficient to lie by, I am resolved to enjoy it, and ride in a smooth harbour all the rest of my days.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: But, Captain, tho' you was so fond of the ocean, and had such success, your nephew may not have the same inclinations, and you should make some allowance.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: No, that's not my way—So, if he has a mind to gain the wind of my affection, he must sheer off from the little frigate he has so long kept in chace, and let me fit him out for a vovage in the Tempest, which sails in a few weeks for the East-Indies.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Then your resolution is fixed—

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: As the Poles.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: And in his absence, I suppose, you intend attacking Miss Flora yourself.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Right, I have some thoughts of bearing down that way.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: But, Captain, don't the great disparity of years between you and her, deter you?

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: No, the more danger, the more honour—Mayhap, you may think it strange, that after steering so long clear of a wife, I should, all of a sudden, veer about, and clap the matrimonial tack aboard.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: He that's long at sea, will find the wind blow from every point of the compass—I have seldom been six months a-shore at one time, since I was a boy, so never had opportunity of coming a-long-side any but such as your Portsmouth or Plymouth fireships, who damage every vessel they grapple with.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: And them, I suppose, you avoided.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Why, ay—So, d'ye see, being lately weather-bound in a trip I made to take observation of some land that lay a-head of Lady Younglove's, I was forced to put into port at her house.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Where you saw her beautiful daughter.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: I did, and in the three glasses we staid there, she drew my heart with as strong an attraction, as ever the loadstone did the needle.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Have you communicated your sentiments to the mother?

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: No, not yet, but I intend shaping my course that way directly.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: I believe, Captain, I can be of service to you in this affair.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: As how, pray?

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: I am this moment going to pay my addresses to the mother.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: What, the old hulk?—Ah, my boy, I'm afraid you are out of your reckoning there—You don't know the trim of her—She'll not be brought to obey either the helm, or the sheet, and if you'll take my advice, you'll e'en let her drop to pieces where she lies at anchor.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: I'll venture, however—The more danger, the more honour, as you say; and if you'll assist me, I don't doubt of succeeding.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Well, well, since the current of your inclination sets that way, I shan't attempt to stem it—thof, let me tell you, she saw her two former consorts go to the bottom, and if you don't take care, you'll share the same fate.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: I confess, I have a terrible prospect, but nothing shall deter me—If you'll suspend your visit, I'll return as soon as our interview is over, and in form you of my success.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Ay, ay, I shall lie by 'till then—But, harkye, Sedley! may I never strike an enemy's flag again, if I would not rather be rak'd fore and aft by a whole French squadron, than stand one broadside from such a Turkish pirate.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: So, den, de milliner introduce your Lady to de Lord Flamwell?

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.p: Oui, I overhear all, and my Lady be just gone to her house.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Diable! I am almost distract!—I no sooner get rid of von rival den anoder start up.

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.p: Patience, Monsieur, we go on ver well—So long as we keep Sedley away, we no fear de rest, but I expect Sir Whifling Trifle, Lady Younglove's broder, tout á l'heure, presently.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: O dat is true, let him come so soon as he will; I am prepare for him.

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.p: Hush! here he be.

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: Now, my pretty Mademoiselle, have I the happiness of finding your Lady at home?

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.p: No, Monsieur, my Lady be just gone out, but here be a Gentleman who has been waiting for you wid de greatest impatience.

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: For me! who is he, pray?

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.p: Monsieur le Marquis de Finesse, un grand voyageur, who be just arrive in England—He hear, par accident, of your visiting my Lady, so—

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: Sir, you do me honour.

sp.speaker: Font.
sp.p: So, now I have introduce him; I'll leave you togeder, and go wait for my Lady.

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: Pray, Sir, may I without offence know the motive of this Interview?

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Curiosity, Monsieur, to see so great a man, whose actions Fame's brazen trompete has blazon'd to every distant part of de world.

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: Oh, dear Sir! this is too much—To be sure, for these thirty years past, I've spent my whole time in the pursuit of objects disregarded by the generality of the world; and, I think, I may without vanity say, that my labours have been successful.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Je le sais bien, Monsieur, I know it, and from a similarity of disposition beg leave to court your acquaintance.

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: I shall be proud of the favour, Sir.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: I have myself, Monsieur, for dese many years past, been a traveller, and collector of de raritie.

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: Sir, you please me very much—may I take the liberty to ask, where you have been, and what curiosities you have collected?

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: De tout mon coeur, Monsieur, wid all my heart—I have travelle over mosht parts of de globe, sometime I ride, sometime I valk, sometime dey carry me against my will—Sometime at my own sharge, and sometime at de publique expence.

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: The public expence?

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Oh, Oui, for de good of de nation—Dat is when I be transporte.

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: Ah, that's an honour I am afraid I shall never arrive at—But pray let's hear.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: In Italy, Prince Palivicini presente me wid a piece of de Vesuvian eruption dat choaka Pliny vid its smoke.

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: Wonderful!—But how are you certain of that?

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Oh, from a worm-eaten manuscript preserve wid it, whereon a P for Pliny, and V for Vesuvio, still visible.

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: Proof, proof enough.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Oh, certainement—proof enough.

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: Had the whole manuscript been preserved it would not have been worth six-pence, but the obscurity always enhances the value.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: I see you be de true Antiquarian, Monsieur.

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: Yes, yes, nobody understands these things better than I do—I have been in Italy myself, and visited the ruins of Herculaneum.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Well! dere you had ample store.

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: Ample indeed—They were guarded with the utmost strictness; nevertheless, by liberally bribing the several persons appointed to watch them, I found means, at different times, to bring away almost a cart-load of legs, arms, and noses belonging to the mutilated statues.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Eft il bien possible?—What a treasure!

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: Yes, and I intend shortly publishing a dozen volumes folio, proving to demonstration, the figures they belonged to.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Oh, it will be of vast import to de publique.

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: Very great, I shall immortalize my name by it—Travels are so much the ton at present, that many go abroad on purpose to oblige the public at their return, with a relation of their wonderful adventures.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: And you be as well qualified as de best of dem.

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: I afterwards made some important discoveries in the North Sea.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: You did!

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: Yes, and actually brought away a large piece of ice from thence.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Et bien! Monsieur—Well, and have you it now?

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: No, the heat of the sun dissolved it in our voyage home.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Unfortunate!

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: Very unfortunate, but travellers are subject to disappointments.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: A la verite, 'tis true, indeed, Monsieur—I have often myself experience de same—Une autre fois, an oder time I vil give you de whole account of all my voyage, but now let a me beg leave to make you de von little present.

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: Present!

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Oui, Monsieur, and such a von as I do flatter myself you will not despise—In my last voyage wid Mons. Bourgainville, touching on de coast of Patagonia, I purchase from von of deir sages an ines;timable jewel.

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: A jewel!

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Not one of dose so called by de Canaille, but an invaluable antique.

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: Is it possible!—I am all impatience—What can it be!

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Le Voici, see here!— (taking on oyster-shell with great form out of a box)—Behold, an Antideluvian cockle shell!

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: I am struck dumb with admiration!

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: And well you may—You see, Monsieur, by de size of it, an undoubted proof of de giantism of old.

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: Bless me!—'Tis as large as a modern oyster, and I protest, seems very like one too.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Right, Monsicur, so it do—You have de great discernment—who knows, indeed noting so probable, dan dat de very cockle shut up in dis, was Manger, eaten by our grand'mere Eve.

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: A happy thought, my friend—Eve's cockle-shell! I am ravish'd at the idea!—But, what return, what recompense can I make for a gem of such—

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: O, noting at all, but de pleasure of your acquaintance—I shall beg leave to see you again, in de evening, at Lady Younglove's.

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: Dear Sir! you do me too much honour.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: C'est Assez, Monsieur, enough—But as it is of such consequence, Sir Whifling, I must request you'll immediately go and deposit it in your cabinet wid your oder curiosities, for fear of accidents.

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: That I will, I assure you, Sir—I came purposely to pay my devoirs to the Goddess of this Mansion, but now beg you'll make my excuses to her—I have now something of more importance to attend to—Yes, yes, I think no one can blame my taste, in preferring an Antideluvian cockle-shell to the finest woman in the creation.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! well said, Old Antiquity—Begar, I believe I shall put de little sheat upon him too—Now, to find Sedley again—I have business enough upon my hand—So much de better——Frenchmen have no occasion to be idle, when Englishmen have so many follies and vices to work upon.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Where can this creature be!—Let me see— (Looking in the glass)—I think this complexion is the most agreeable to black—One can't be too nice in suiting the complexion to the dress.
Where have you been, Frippery?

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Ordering a fresh quantity of your Ladyship's cordial, as you complained that the last was not strong enough.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: You are a good girl—Has that impudent fellow, Woodford, been here to-day?

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: No, Madam; the answer your Ladyship gave him yesterday, will refer him from coming any more.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: I am very glad of it—An unmannerly rake-hell, not worth a shilling, to have the asfurance to make love to a child before my face.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: 'Twas monstraceous rude, indeed, Madam—Had he the sense to have paid his congratulations to your Ladyship, he might have been forgiven.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: True, Frippery; I cou'd much sooner pass over an affront of that sort offered to myself, than her.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: That I am sure of— (aside)—Really, Madam, the exquisitive charms of your Ladyship would be a sufficient excuse for such an act of insensibility.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: O, fie, girl! how can you talk in such a manner?—What charms can a woman of forty be supposed to have?

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Fifty, would be nearer the mark. (aside.)—Your Ladyship certainly mistakes your age.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: How! mistake my age—Surely, hussey, you don't mean—

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Yes, Madam; for by your looks, I should take my book oath, that you were not above five-and-twenty.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Oh!—Why, I believe I do look very well for my years.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p:
Years!—Lud, Ma'am, how can you talk so abruptly?—As I am a woman of veracity, your Ladyship only looks like Miss Flora's eldest sister,
and are young enough to have half a dozen husbands yet.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: You are a merry girl, and always striving to divert your poor disconsolate mistress—Alas! my sweet, dear man has been dead above three months, and no one has said a civil thing to me yet.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Mr. Sedley, to wait upon your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Shew him up—Bless me! what can he want with me?

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Your Ladyship's most obedient—How shall I apologize for this rudeness, Madam?

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: O, dear Sir! there is not the least occasion—I think you are very kind thus to visit a poor, distressed, afflicted widow.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: You are goodness itself, Madam—I have waited on you now, my Lady, upon a very particular affair, which demands a few moments privacy.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Frippery, you may retire.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Yes, my Lady—Hem!—but by virtue of my office, I'll make bold to listen; so, wise Sir, you might as well have let me staid.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Now, Madam, that we are alone, can you forgive the folly, the presumption, the—call it what you please—which urged me on to this rash attempt?

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Upon my word, Sir, I can't comprehend you.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: And yet, when you shall know how long I have sighed in secret, how long been tortured with despair, before I dare pronounce the sacred name of love—

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Love, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Yes, Madam; who could behold such beauty, and not adore?

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: So! Miss has got another lover, I find, but I'll soon silence him. (aside) Really, Sir, this is a language I must not suffer—'Tis highly improper for a child like mine to hear, these many years to come.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Child, Madam!—Is it possible you can mistake my meaning?

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Why, Sir, was not all this designed for my daughter?

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: For Miss Flora, Madam!—No, as your Ladyship's daughter, she could not but have some charms; but I must be blind indeed, to offer up my vows to such a baby—You'll excuse my freedom, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Oh, readily, Sir.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: 'Tis you, my Lady, who are the blooming Goddess of my adoration—Oh, how can I express the inconceivable torments of my breast, for those many years past!—During Sir Solomon's life, fear of offending tied up my tongue to a painful silence, and I was obliged to—

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: I assure you, Sir, I pity you, and had I known your sufferings, wou'd have contrived some method of softening them.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: I am transported to hear it—After his death, respect still sealed up my lips, 'till I found—for love, Madam, is Argus-eyed—that Mr. Woodford frequented this house, and was, without doubt, a favour'd lover—This made me resolve to discover my hopeless passion, wait his arrival here, and thro' a happy rival's bosom, force my way to that heart which kings might be proud to call their own!

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Hold, Sir, you are in an error—'Twas not to me, but my daughter, his devoirs were paid.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Pardon me, Madam, I cannot suppose Mr. Woodford so insensible, as to think of any other object, when you are present.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: O, dear Sir, he has not half the complaisance you have!—What a charming man he is!

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: My character, and family, Madam, you are no stranger to—My estate is considerable, and, if it is not too great a presumption, give me leave to cast both it, and a heart unalterably devoted to you, at your feet.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: O, rise, dear Sir—You overwhelm me with confusion!—Sure, you cannot possibly find any thing so attracting in a face, which constant grief has made such an impression on.

sp.speaker: Sedley
sp.p: Hem! Now for a little more nonsense. (aside) Come, my beauteous widow, cast aside these weeds of sorrow, and be arrayed in robes more splendid, and more becoming such a divinity.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Impossible—I fear, Sir!

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Impossble!

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Almost, Sir—What will the world say of so hasty, so precipitate an act?

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Umph! I find her coming. (aside) Love, Madam, will plead for all—'Tis a crime against his power to resist—Besides, enough you have sacrificed to sorrow—Three months at least.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Oh, Sir, more—Sixteen weeks tomorrow—But, what are sixteen weeks, sixteen months, or sixteen years, to mourn the loss of so good a man.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Come, Madam, no more of these melancholy reflections—The only remedy in the world for a lady's immoderate grief on the loss of a favourite, be it monkey, lap-dog, or husband, is to get another.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Indeed, Sir, I believe you are perfectly right—I remember, some years ago, I was utterly inconsolable on the death of a beautiful parrot, 'till the loss was supplied by an enchanting owl, which was presented me.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Then let me, Madam, by the warmth of my passion, dry up your tears for Sir Solomon Younglove.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Surely, Sir, you are uncommonly persuading—Well! to try your constancy, if you persevere in your intention, till my year of widowhood be expired, I don't know but I may be tempted to reward it.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: A year, Madam!—An age!—For heaven's sake, my dear Lady, have some compassion.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Believe me, Sir, I am very compassionate.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Wou'd you have me die at your feet?

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: No, not for the world—Rather than you should do that, I will shorten it—to—to half the time.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: She soon drops. (aside) Still, madam, I find you are cruelly resolved not to make me happy, therefore hopeless, and despairing, let me bid you eternally, eternally, adieu!

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Stay, sir, stay—Must not I pay my last husband the same compliment I did my first?

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: What was that madam?

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Wait five short, short months.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Look you, my Lady, I would do as I would be done by—If you survive me, you have my consent to marry again the next day.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: I confess, sir, you are the most reasonable man I ever met with.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: But, I see, madam, you are inexorable, so must retire, and in secret, lament my adverse fortune.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Dear sir, stay—What can I say? I vow you are quite irresistible—Well, then,—though overwhelm'd with blushes—To-morrow, I consent to be yours.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Retard not my joy so long, but let this night crown my happiness—I see a kind consenting smile sparkle in your eye, and thus, I thank you (Kisses her) Oh, zounds! that was too much!

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Who can withstand such rhetoric!—You have conquered, sir, and I surrender at discretion.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: And now, my dear Lady, as our interests are to be one—If you give me leave, I can assist you in disposing of Miss Flora.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: You cou'd not oblige me more, sir, for, poor child! she seems in great haste to be married.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Not so much as her mother, I'll be sworn. (aside) I think, my Lady, I could recommend one you can have no objection to—Captain Helm, your neighbour.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Captain Helm—Do you think that possible?

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Nothing easier, if your Ladyship does not chuse to prevent it.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: I prevent it; heavens forbid!—Poor dear child, it wou'd be a happy day for her.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Happy, indeed, madam.—He has been raving about Miss, ever since his accidentally seeing her in the country, and longing for an opportunity of declaring himself—Nay, more—he knows of my visit to you, and hopes this evening will unite both parties.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: I'm sure I would do any thing in reason to secure her felicity.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Captain Helm, madam, is prodigiously in love, vet has many odd whims, and like the element he belongs to, is very subject to change.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Oh, if he was once bound, we'd give him leave to change.

sp.speaker: Sedl.
sp.p: True, madam, therefore we had better make short work of it, and take him while he is in the humour.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p:
Well! do just as you please, dear
Mr. Seley—I am now your property, so dispose of me and mine, as you like.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: I'll step directly to my lawyer's to prepare the deeds, then return with Captain Helm—Meantime, my lovely charmer! divest yourself of those beauty-veiling weeds, relumine the circle you were wont to shine in, and prepare to bless the happiest mortal in the world!

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: What a bewitching man!—But, there is not a moment to lose, I must set about making the necessary preparations immediately—Well, who could have thought when I got up this morning, that I should be a bride before night.—O, lud! a third husband is a happiness I never expected.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: So! Upon my word, a tender scene, and quite curry-curristical—When Miss and her old seamonster join them, they'll make a nice trio—But, it is unpossible all this can be real on his side; and if my old Lady was not so tosticated with her good fortune, she might easily find it out—Oh, here comes Miss, now we shall hear her sentances of the matter.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Frippery, what's the matter with my mama? I met her this moment in unusual spirits, and she ordered me to follow her into her dressing-room.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Spirits!—A third husband is enough to put any woman turned of sifty into spirits—Heaven help me! though I am half that age, I have not got one yet.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: What do you mean, Frippery?

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: I mean, that your mama's going to be married, to-night.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: To-night!

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Yes, to-night.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: More shame for her.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Ay, so say I.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: I'm sure it wou'd be fitter for her to get me a husband first.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Oh! you are to be married at the same time.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Am I?—I'm afraid that's too good news to be true.—But tell me sincerely, are not you joking now?

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Not I, upon my word.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Well, that is charming!—Only feel what a palpitation it has caused here,—for all the world like the fluttering of my little Robin Red-breast.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Ay, my dear, I have often had such flustrations.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: And does Mr. Woodford know it?

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Mr. Woodford, Lord, Miss, he is not to be the man.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: No!—Who then?

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Why, his uncle, Captain Helm, who you remember visited us some time ago in the country.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: What, that ugly old fright, who I compar'd to King Priam in the puppet-shew?

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: The very idential man, Miss.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Was there ever anything so ridiculous!—A husband, Ha! ha! ha!—O yes, to be sure he's a very proper husband for a girl of my age and spirit.—It is a wonder, Frippery, she did not think of a dancing bear for me—I'm sure, he's much the more agreeable and polish'd animal of the two.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Indeed, Miss, I must say, that he's the most oddest, damphibious looking creature I ever saw—But your mama intends to make you have him, or not a penny of fortune.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p:
A fig for fortune, say I.—Before she should sacrafice me to such a compound of age and infirmity, I'd bid adieu to all ideas of future grandeur,
and boldly fly, with the man of my heart, to those regions of love and happiness, where true content is only to be found.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: My Lady desires you, Mrs. Frippery, to go directly for her diamond ear-rings, that are mending at the jeweller's, and not to stay a moment, for she wants you in all haste to help her to dress.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: So! she's in a hurry, I find.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Hurry! ecod, I believe she's possest—she has order'd us all to get on our state liveries, that were made in her first husband's time, and the housekeeper is to provide such a supper, that, lud have mercy upon me!—Hark! her bell rings.— [Exit; returns.] Oh, I had forgot—Miss Flora, you are to go to your mama directly.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Tell her, I won't, John.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: No, John, tell her she's coming.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Well, do just as you please for that.—Coming, my Lady, coming—Zounds! I wish the bell was tied about your neck.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: My dear, you must go—endeavour to humour your mama now.—Only seem to be agreeable to her marriage, and perhaps she may not insist on yours.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Nay, I did not care if she married a new husband every month, so she'd only let me have Mr. Woodford; and I'm sure that's not unreasonable.—But will you, my dear Frippery, in the mean time, endeavour to find him out, and let him know my distress?

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: That I will, I'll ensure you.—Do you think I cou'd refuse any thing in my power, to help such a couple of true lovyers?—No, no, Frippery always does as she'd be done by—and, I'm sure all I wait for myself is,—the man to ask me the question.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Well!—Some girls now, in my situation, wou'd, in despair of relief, hang or drown themselves, and so put an end to their adventures at once. To be sure, my situation is very critical—Solely dependant on a mother—Denied the man I love, and obliged to receive the odious addresses of one I hate, are difficulties not easily surmounted—Yet, a good heart, and a fertile head, may do much—And if I do surmount them, I think I shall deserve a statue raising to my constancy and fidelity.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Well, my good mother, what success?—I have been upon the rack ever since you went—Come, tell me—Any hopes?

sp.speaker: Fash.
sp.p: Hopes!—When did you know me undertake any thing that fail'd?

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: But, have you mention'd me?

sp.speaker: Fash.
sp.p: Yes, yes, I have done more for you than ever your own mother did—Look you, I expect no less than a thousand pounds for my share—Ay, all signed and sealed before consummation.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: You shall have it without the least scruple.

sp.speaker: Fash.
sp.p: Scruple, indeed!—A hundred a year for life.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Certainly.

sp.speaker: Fash.
sp.p: An elegant house, ready furnished.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: All very reasonable.

sp.speaker: Fash.
sp.p: Ay, I was always remarked for my reason and moderation.—Well! after this affair is over, I shall have nothing to do, but to live with credit and character, the rest of my days.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Then you think we shall succeed?

sp.speaker: Fash.
sp.p: Quite certain of it.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: You transport me!

sp.speaker: Fash.
sp.p: Such a lovely, tender, sweet chicken!—Ah, rogue, if you should not behave well to her, you'll break my heart.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Oh, never fear that—You know I am a man of the strictest honour.

sp.speaker: Fash.
sp.p: Yes, I have had many proofs of your honour. (aside.) Ay, 'tis that consideration alone which urges me on—I would not have helped her to every body, for heaven knows, it is not the little trash I am to get by it, that—

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: No, to be sure.

sp.speaker: Fash.
sp.p: I say, 'tis not the trifle I am to get by it, but the surety of providing her with a good husband.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: But all this while you keep me in suspence—What said she?—When may I hope to see her?

sp.speaker: Fash.
sp.p: Said! no bird ever fell into a fowler's snare so readily—She believes every syllable about your title and fortune, is as impatient as you are for an interview, and promis'd to be here directly.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Egad, you have made quick work of it—Be here directly—Zounds! I am afraid I shall want assurance to go through with it.

sp.speaker: Fash.
sp.p: After what you have gone through already, I think there can be no great danger now.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: You must introduce me properly, else, as I have never seen her, I may make some mistake.

sp.speaker: Fash.
sp.p: I must own your head is not the best in the world, but here you can't readily go wrong—Be fure you keep up to your part—Talk of the years you have been dying for her in secret—Flatter her charms to the utmost—Speak highly of your family and connections—If you should make some trifling blunders, I'll place them to the excess of your passion—The most pleasing excuse which can be given to a woman fond of adoration.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: As for that matter, you know I am seldom at a loss for words.

sp.speaker: Fash.
sp.p: Yes, I know the height of your oratory, but let me tell you, she must be attack'd in a very different manner from the nymphs you have been used to.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Well, well, I'll take care now to be on the other side, and be as high-flown as possible—I have been studying hard words for that purpose.

sp.speaker: Fash.
sp.p: As I live, that's her rap—She's impatient indeed!

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Zounds! I am quite unprepared—What shall I do?

sp.speaker: Fash.
sp.p: Receive her as if by accident—She'll pretend she's come to me, but I'll not appear till the first ceremonies are over.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Hold—Don't leave us together.

sp.speaker: Fash.
sp.p: Not another word, but make good use of your time.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: I wish with all my soul, it was over—Hem! hem!

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Ma'am—your—your—most unlimitedly—obedient—I, I am—that is to say—extravagantly happy—in—in—in—

sp.speaker: Miss Belg.
sp.p: I was told, sir, that Mrs. Fashion was here.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Ay, that's right. (aside) Hem! hem!—She only gave place, illustrious Lady, to let the resplendency of your charms shine in their meridian lustre!—Hem! hem!

sp.speaker: Miss Belg.
sp.p: Sir!—Is it to me you address this discourse?

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Who else, thou sovereign object of my wishes!—I have languish'd whole years for the happiness of this interview, and now, I—

sp.speaker: Miss Belg.
sp.p: Hold, sir,—I am not to be treated in this ludicrous manner—Do you know who I am?

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p:
Do the inhabitants of this nether world know the radiant sun that daily illumines them?—
You, my angelic Miss Bloomer, are my sun, my moon, my stars, my whole planetary system!—Pretty well that, I think.

sp.speaker: Miss Belg.
sp.p: Miss Bloomer!—Ha! there must be some trick in this—Some design on my fair friend—I'll fathom it.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: She hesitates—I believe I have done it—Bravo, my boy, I never knew your eloquence fail.

sp.speaker: Miss Belg.
sp.p: Pray, sir, who are you?

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Ah, madam! I am the unhappy Lord Flamwell, heir to one of the most noble families in England, with an independant fortune in my own possession, which, with the most glowing heart that ever was offered up to Cytherea's goddess, I now present to you, my Cyprian Venus.

sp.speaker: Miss Belg.
sp.p: And all this is designed for me?

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Alas! where's the merit in paying worship to the queen of beauty?—No, my adorable Miss Bloomer, I long have loved, but till this happy moment, never had courage to tell you so.

sp.speaker: Miss Belg.
sp.p: And I am to believe all this real?

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Every syllable of it true, by those bright eyes!

sp.speaker: Mrs. FASHION
sp.p: My dear Miss Bloomer! this is so kind of you to call on—Ah! what do I see!—Miss Belgrove!—My Lord, what are you about?

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Curse me if I know!— (Rises, looks confusedly, first at Miss Belgrove, then at Mrs. Fashion)—Oh, my evil stars! what have I done now?

sp.speaker: Miss Belg.
sp.p: Upon my word, Mrs. Fashion, I am very glad you are come—You, perhaps, can explain this gentleman's meaning, which, I confess, is above my comprehension.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fash.
sp.p:
My dear, sweet Miss Belgrove—This
gentleman—is a—a Lord—that—that—a—his friends have confined in my house for lunacy.

sp.speaker: Miss Belg.
sp.p: I beg your pardon, Mrs. Fashion, I did not know till now, that you kept a private madhouse.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fash.
sp.p: Ah, poor nobleman! he's greatly to be pitied—All this is a love affair, Miss—Gone quite distracted for love.

sp.speaker: Miss Belg.
sp.p: For love!—And are you so famous for curing mad people?—Now, I think I could recommend a magistrate for his doctor, who could much sooner restore him to his senses.

sp.speaker: Fash.
sp.p: Oh, your Ladyship mistakes him quite—As innocent as a new-born babe—But, pray let me attend you into another room.

sp.speaker: Miss Belg.
sp.p: I shan't stop—I only wanted to consult you about the choice of some Brussells lace.

sp.speaker: Fash.
sp.p: I'll wait on your Ladyship, at your own house directly.

sp.speaker: Miss Belg.
sp.p: Whenever you are at leisure.—Mean time, let me advise that gentleman, not to be so violent in his raptures, before he is certain of the person he addresses them to.

sp.speaker: Fash.
sp.p: Ah, you are a witty Lady—Nay, by my saith, I'll wait on you to the door—This is so great an honour to call (Turns and looks back at Flamwell) Ah! conjuror.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Tol, lol, lol. (singing) I believe it is all over—Ay, ay, my old luck pursues me still, and if ever I do cut a distinguisning figure in the world, I'm afraid it will be when I make my exit.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fash.
sp.p: Your humble servant, good Mr. Blunder—You have made a notable piece of work here.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: What shall I do?

sp.speaker: Fash.
sp.p: Hang, or drown yourself—'tis all over now.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Was there ever so unlucky a dog!

sp.speaker: Fash.
sp.p: Never—that I'll answer for—Nothing prospers you undertake—What the deuce could possess you to make so egregious a mistake?

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Zounds! you—You knew I had never seen Miss Bloomer, and your declaring it was her, left me not the least room to doubt.

sp.speaker: Fash.
sp.p: Nothing could be more unfortunate!—The two ladies are intimate, and if a discovery should ensue, I am entirely ruined.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Can you think of nothing to prevent it?

sp.speaker: Fash.
sp.p: I expect the real Miss Bloomer every minute—When she's gone, I'll wait upon Miss Belgrove, and endeavour to persuade her, that you really are a lunatic—And faith, if this affair fails, I shall be little better myself. (Knocking) Hark! I believe this is she, in reality—Away, and be in readiness, if I should want you.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Hearky'!—Take care how you introduce me to the next Miss Bloomer.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Now, Fashion, I am as good as my word, you see.

sp.speaker: Fash.
sp.p: Heaven bless you! that you always are.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: But come, I have not a moment to lose.

sp.speaker: Fash.
sp.p: Ah, that sweet countenance!—I don't wonder so many gentlemen despair of obtaining so great a prize.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: What do you mean?

sp.speaker: Fash.
sp.p: I am sure I can't blame the extravagance of Lord Flamwell's passion—And, by my faith, he swears he can't live without you.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Lord Flamwell!—Who is he, pray?

sp.speaker: Fash.
sp.p: The young nobleman, I told your Ladyship about this morning—Well, a sweeter, better humour'd, or more generous man, was never seen—Had you beheld with what transports he received the news of your coming hither.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Why, surely, you did not tell him any such thing?

sp.speaker: Fash.
sp.p: Really, Miss, he look'd so piteously, I cou'd not help it—Oh, Mrs. Fashion, says he, if my beauteous angel will but consent to be mine, how happy shall I be!—My whole fortune shall be at her command—What pleasure shall I take in introducing her to my Sisters, Lady Lucy, Lady Sophia, and Lady Harriet.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Bless me! the Gentleman seems to have a number of relations—But I have not time to lose about such trifles.

sp.speaker: Fash.
sp.p: Do you call breaking a nobleman's heart, a trifle?

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Yes—to me the greatest trifle in the world.

sp.speaker: Fash.
sp.p: Ah, you'll pay for all, one day or other—But, do now, give me leave to introduce him to you.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Who, me?—Not I, I positively assure you—'Tis your own house, you know, and if you chuse to do it—I can't help you.

sp.speaker: Fash.
sp.p: Well, I'll venture your displeasure—I'm sure you would not be the death of any person, nor discompose that sweet face of yours with a frown, for the world.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: What a fool am I, to be flatter'd by such a fulsome old woman—I am certainly an odd composition—to be pleased with what at the same time I so much despise—Now, for my Lord—If his heart does not speedily go pit-a-pit, and I don't make him as great a rool as I have dome the rest of my admirers, why I'll contess, I've lost the art of tormenting.

sp.speaker: Fash.
sp.p: Miss Bloomer, Lord Flamwell, who has long wish'd to pay his respects to you.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Hold, my Lord, we must be upon a more intimate footing, before I allow liberties of that sort.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: I stand justly reproved, Madam, for my presumption, and own I merit the fate of—of—Icarus, who drove the Chariot of Apollo—Yet, if you'll but—

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!—Your Lordship must pardon this emotion, which the profundity of your learning has involuntarily extorted from me—Ha! ha! ha! If I don't mistake, Icarus was a near relation of yours.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Of mine, Madam,—Yes—No, no, he has been dead, for ought I can tell, these—these hundred years past.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! I know it, my Lord, but you certainly are of the same family, and endeavour to imitate him, in soaring so high.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: If I have committed any error, your charms, Madam, are a sufficient excuse.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: True, my Lord, my charms have led many people into very great errors, and if you don't take care, you'll stand in the same predicament.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: I wish it, Madam.—If I am so conspicuously happy, as to possess you, I shall be the envy of the gaping world—Adorable creature! behold, thus prostrate at your feet, the unhappy Lord Flamwell, who vows never more to rise, till you have put a period to his sufferings.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: And that, I vow, my Lord, will never be.

sp.speaker: Fash.
sp.p: Ah, the sweet youth! it brings tears into my eyes, to see what a condition love has reduced him to.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p:
Pray, my Lord, let's have that speech
over again—Stay, you shall see how gracefully it comes from me in heroics.
sp.l: Thus at your feet, Pomposo Flamwell lies,
There vows to stay, until you bid him—rise.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: I find she's an overmatch for me, every way.

sp.speaker: Fash.
sp.p: Come, Miss Bloomer, let me put in a word for his Lordship—As I can answer for the sincerity and honourableness of his intentions, I hope you'll not stand on unnecessary punctilio—You see he cannot live without you—Reward his passion with your hand, and let me this evening, salute you Lady Flamwell.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Thou, more than Goddess! if you judge my fortune, title, or family, not beneath your acceptance, bless me with your love, and crown my wishes.

sp.speaker: Fash.
sp.p: Ay, I see a kind consenting look in these pretty tell-tale sparklers—Just so, I look'd myself, on such an occasion—By my faith, we'll have a wedding directly—Let your Lordship's Chaplain be call'd in, and the ceremony immediately performed.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Hold, hold, pray let me get in a word with you—Look you, my Lord, I have not been used to such treatment, nor do I understand your meaning—As to you, Mrs. Fashion, I am surprized you don't know me better—But, be assur'd, as this is the first time I've been in your house, so it shall be the last.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Stay, charming, cruel tyrant, and take my life before you go.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: What use shall I make of it, my Lord?—You had better make a present of it to some other person, who prefers a title before understanding, and wealth beyond happiness.

sp.speaker: Fash.
sp.p: My dear Miss Bloomer, how can you be angry with me?—If my Lord loves you to distraction, am I to blame, in endeavouring to promote your future felicity?

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Then will you not give me leave to hope?—And must those charms, which like the sun dispense their refreshing beams around the celestial hemisphere, be only withheld from me?

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: My Lord, tho' I believe nobility and common sense very compatible, yet, as you are not happily possessed of both, forgive me if I decline your very generous offer—And, be certain, if ever I do resign my freedom, it shall be to a man who knows how to set a proper value on it.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: And, curse catch me! if ever I am master of if, if I don't make you heartily repent this treatment.

sp.speaker: Fash.
sp.p: Go, you deserve it all, for being so great an ideot.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Zounds! woman, what would you have me do?—I spoke better than ever I did in my life before, but the Devil is not a match for such a tongue.

sp.speaker: Fash.
sp.p: No, not such an ignorant Devil as you—But, she shan't escape so—Ill after her, and endeavour to repair your mistakes, then make my last bold effort—So, prepare yourself—the conclusion of this business will certainly be a wife, or—a halter!

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: A wife, by all means—Of Two Evils, I always chuse the least.

div3.head: SCENE, LADY YOUNGLOVE'S.
div3.stage: Enter Lady YOUNGLOVE, drest, and FLORA,

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: How can you, Child, make all this noise about One Husband, when you see, I have been oblig'd to have Two already, and am now under the cruel necessity of preparing for a Third.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Yes, and that same cruel necessity would oblige you to marry a score, if you could.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: Mr. Sedley, and Capt. Helm, to wait upon your Ladyship.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Admit them.
sp.stage: Enter SEDLEY, Capt. HELM, and SWAB.
sp.p: Gentlemen, you are very welcome.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: So, Widow! I understand you are hound for another voyage—Lookee, if the wind sits fair, belike I shall bear you company.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: I am much obliged to you, Captain, for your good wishes, and hope my daughter may entertain a proper sense of them.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: O, yes, he may be assur'd, that I entertain a very proper sense of them.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Thank you, thank you, Widow—Suppose I haul a chair, and sound the coast, to see how the land lies.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Do, Captain—meantime, my fair widow and I have some private affairs to settle, that will require our absence for a few minutes—Madam, will you indulge me so far—

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Dear Sir, I can't deny you any thing you ask—
sp.stage: [Sedley hands her out with great ceremony.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: So, so!—they have left me to the mercy of this frightful Man of War—Now, for a love-scene of the tenderest kind.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Swab! go below—And, d'ye see, look out for a snug birth, call for a can of flip, and keep a tight reckoning, till I pipe you up again.

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: I will, your honour, and drink success to the chace.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Now we are alone, I don't know what to say to her—By the mess, I begin to find I've got out of my element.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Well, I really think he is ten times uglier than when I saw him last.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Hem?—If I was but once afloat, shou'd do well enough.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p:
What a pretty lover he makes—Poor
wretch!—I think I must plague him a little—Yes, yes, I must have some sport with him.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: That it shou'd ever come to this!—I who have attacked so many first-rate men of war, now to be afraid of a little cock-boat.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Pray, Captain, what makes you look so very grum?—If you are not well. I'll go and fetch some of my Mama's stomachic cordial for you.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Hold, Miss, I am pretty well, thank you—Hem!— (After some preparation) Pray, Miss, were you ever at sea?

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: A good beginning—O, yes, Captain, very often—Why, I once went with my mama as far as Greenwich.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Well, Miss, what think you now, of a voyage to the Land of Matrimony?

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Voyage!—Why, I always thought that people went by land to be married—Now, I shou'd like to be married very well,—but not to you.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: All above board, I find—Mayhap, Miss, you may think my timbers are not sound, and that I want to be hove down—But, let me tell you, I am heartier than many, whose gingerbread rigging fly full in the wind's eye.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Gingerbread rigging!—I'm sure, I'd rather have a gingerbread husband, than you.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Ay, why so?

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Because, when I was tired of playing with it, I could eat it.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Nay, if you be like the cannibals, Miss, I had best sheer off—tho', I believe you'd find me very hard of digestion.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Very likely, but I shan't try.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: However, Miss, all this is little to the purpose.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Ay, indeed, and so it is sure enough—So, as you have nothing more to say, I think I had best leave you to yourself.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Avast, avast!—If you are for running a-head so, I must bring you to your bearings.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Ah, but you can't tho', for I never will bear you.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Lookee, d'ye see, Miss, I came hither to have some serious discourse with you, because as how I intended to have mess'd with you for life, but if so be you can't steer a steady course without all this tacking, why, it will be a thing impossible to grapple with you for half a glass together.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Well, then, I will speak my mind, tho' Mama shou'd lock me up for it—I detest the sight of you—if you were as handsome as you are ugly, and as young as you are old, yet still I shou'd hate you—My heart is set upon Mr. Woodford, and have him I will, tho' I creep through an iron grate, or jump out of a garret window to him.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: So! she has slipt her anchor, and run out to sea; while I am all aground here, and must wait for a spring tide to set me afloat again.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Well, Mr. Sedley, your arguments are so persuasive, there's no resisting them—I consent then, that both marriages be celebrated this evening.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: And, to free you from any jealousy of Miss Bloomer, I request, Madam, that she may be invited as a witness, on this joyful occasion.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: I vow, that's cruel in you, besides, poor Lady! it will look like insult in me—But, bless me, Captain, where's the child gone to?

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Right a head, yonder, sailing in the wind's eye.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Well, Captain, what success?

sp.speaker: Helm.
