sp.p: Success!—Why, d'ye see, I believe I have steer'd by a wrong chart, and mayhap, if I don't tack about, I may chance to be wreck'd upon the shallows.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p:
Oh, dear Captain, von must not mind
her—She's young and ignorant of her good—I was just so at her age, but she'll know better before long.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Why, to be sure, Widow, I do think she wants a little teaching, and will lay a wager, she does not know a cat from a capstan—But, no matter for that,—all in good time—patience is a good stream anchor—If I thought I stood fair for the harbour of her good-will, why, 'tis not a little squally weather, or variation of the wind, should hinder me from venturing.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: I'll ensure your successing—My Lady and I have entirely settled matters—At our return in the evening, every thing is to be finally concluded—You'll have your writings ready.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Ay, ay, I can produce the log-book of my estate at a minute's warning.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: And, Captain, I think the greatest punishment you can inflict on your nephew for his disobedience, will be to oblige him to be a spectator of the ceremony.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Right, my Boy, so it will.

sp.speaker: Serv.
sp.p: A letter for Mr. Sedley.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: For me!—With your leave, my Lady.—

Sir,
—If there remains the least spark of tenderness in your bosom for Miss Bloomer, fly to extricate her from an affair that threatens the destruction of her peace and happiness—There is no time to be loss—Come to my House directly, and I'll inform you of particulars.
F. BELGROVE.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Miss Bloomer!—Her very name has raised a tumult in my soul!

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Dear Mr. Sedley, you seem discomposed—

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: No, Madam, perfectly easy.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Sure no unlucky accident has happened to disturb our happiness?

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: No, Madam, none.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: I'm afraid there has,—You had better stay here till every thing is over.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Fulsome old Witch! (aside) Importance, Madam, some urgent business demands me for a little time—I shall not stav long.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Mr. Sedley—And may I depend upon you?

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Undoubtedly, Madam.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Stay, Mr. Sealey—Perhaps, this is some affair with a lady, and—

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Don't be uneasy, Madam,—Was there ever any thing so provoking (aside.) Captain, you'll excuse me, I'll send up your servant.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Stay, stay, another word—Had not I better accompany you, and then—

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Pray, Madam, stay till I come back, and then—your may go to Jamaica, if you please.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Oh, the sweet creature!—I wish this affair was over—If I should be disappointed now—Well, I shan't have a moment's comfort, till I have absolutely secured him mine.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: And, noint my block, if ever you'll let him have a moment's comfort afterwards.
Steady, boys, steady!

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Hey!—Avast!—What's here?

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: All's safe—all's safe, your honour— (hiccups)steady, steady's the word—No of bilging, while Swab keeps a dead reckoning.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: You lubberly dog! how came you in this trim?

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: No matter—All's safe—I've been tossing the Can to Mrs. Erippery's health—And now, if your worship's glory will turn out, we will scud homewards with a loom gale.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: You deserve to be lash'd to the gangway, you drunken water-spout, and if I come along side of you, I'll be soon foul of your forelights.

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: Bless you precious limbs, no, no, noble Captain, safe's the word, safe's the word—I'm the man will stand by you, while I have a stick standing, or can carry a rag of canvass—So, follow in my wake, as soon as you please.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Sheer off—do—The dog knows I regard him for old acquantance sake,—To be sure, a better sailor never step'd upon forecastle—He has work'd many a hard gale, and never flinched—ah! 'tis such brave fellows as he, that man our fleets, and shew our topsails to the enemy—Ay, ay, Old England may well say, that a British seaman, is one of the nobiest characters, the word can boast of.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: I Own to you, Miss Belgrove, that, so far from being indifferent about Miss Bloomer, my heart never was more devoted to her, than at present—In vain, my reason shews the folly of my conduct, love has got possession of my soul with such absolute dominion, that every other passion bows to its resistless sway.

sp.speaker: Miss Belg.
sp.p: Certainly, you Lovers, are the most inconsistent set of beings in the world—Absolute contradictions—You love and hate, swear and forswear, whine and rage;—Resolve one moment, and break it the next—Tear the false image from your hearts this hour, and worship it with the grossest adulation the following one.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: I confess it, Madam, yet in me you'll not behold such a Proteus—I can love, without being blind.

sp.speaker: Miss Belg.
sp.p: Impossible, for all lovers are blind, at least to the faults of their mistresses—But, no more of this—Take my word for it, Miss Bloomer is deserving of your best wishes, and, tho' I cannot entirely defend the sprightly, tho' sometimes, imprudent sallies of my fair friend; yet, I think them so venially agreeable, that they almost carry their excuse in the commission.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: And, yet, in the present case, 'tis certain she encourages the addresses of some designing rascal, who, probably wants to make a prey of her person and fortune.

sp.speaker: Miss Belg.
sp.p: I own it looks like it—When I saw her this morning, she hinted a new conquest of a Lord, and by the circumstances, I suspect Mrs. Fashion of being the contriver of the whole design.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Have you seen Miss Bloomer since you left Mrs. Fashion's?

sp.speaker: Miss Belg.
sp.p: No, I called at her house directly after, but she was not at home, upon which, apprehending some bad consequences, I thought the best thing I could do, would be to acquaint you, and request your assistance.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: You oblige me infinitely, Madam—I'll unravel this villainy, or—

sp.speaker: Miss Belg.
sp.p: Stay, do nothing unadvisedly—Let me go again to Miss Bloomer's, and endeavour to learn whether she has seen this impostor.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: You are right, Madam—But, pray, don't drop a hint of your suspicions—Conviction will come stronger, when attended with danger, and open detection—Meanwhile, I'll just step home, and be back time enought for your return.

sp.speaker: Miss Belg.
sp.p: Poor Gentleman!—Oh, Lud! what fools this Love makes of the wisest of us—I swear, if the whimsical, inconsistent urchin, dare have the assurance to attack me, I'd muster up all my courage, and—and—run away from him, as fast as I could.

div3.head: SCENE, Miss BLOOMER'S.
div3.stage: Enter Miss BLOOMER, and Mrs. FASHION.

sp.speaker: Mrs. Fash.
sp.p: Oh, my dear Lady! what an unfortunate woman am I?

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Bless me! what new matter for wonder?—Have you made another mistake?

sp.speaker: Fash.
sp.p: Surely, I was born to be unhappy!

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: I can't help saying, you deserve it—The next time I call at your house, you shall suffer me to be affronted in the manner I was last.

sp.speaker: Fash.
sp.p: You have ample revenge, I can assure you—Oh, I shall never forgive myself, no, not if I was to live a thousand years, for being accessary to the death of so sweet, so lovely, so good-natured a gentleman.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Death! whose death?

sp.speaker: Fash.
sp.p: And yet, alas! I am innocent—'Tis those bright eyes alone, that have done all this mischief.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Oh, if that be all, I'll readily undertake to cure all the evil done by them.

sp.speaker: Fash.
sp.p: No, no, he's too far gone to cure—He's a dying man.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Dying!—Who in the name of wonder is dying?

sp.speaker: Fash.
sp.p: Lord Flamwell—No sooner had you left the house, than, seiz'd with a fit of despair, he shut himself up in his chamber, and—

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Rayed like a madman, then, when he was tired—let himself out again.

sp.speaker: Fash.
sp.p: How can you be so barbarous!—But mark the consequences—He had searce been a quarter of an hour there, when we were alarmed with the groans of a dying person, and forcing the door open, found him weltring in his blood.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Oh, heavens! is it true?

sp.speaker: Fash.
sp.p: A surgeon was immediately sent for, but on examination, he declared the wound mortal, and that nothing could save his life.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: I am petrified with horror!

sp.speaker: Fash.
sp.p: Oh! oh! oh! (crying) that ever I should live to see this day!—The sweet youth!—I loved him, as if he had been my own son!—What will his family say to me?—Oh! oh! oh! oh!

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: But, are there no hopes of his recovery?

sp.speaker: Fash.
sp.p: No, not the least—He can't live two hours!

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Poor gentleman!—I sincerely pity him.

sp.speaker: Fash.
sp.p: Ah! what signifies pity—If you would make him some amends for your cruelty, and condescend to visit him directly—

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: I visit him!

sp.speaker: Fash.
sp.p: Yes—consider can you be so hard-hearted as refuse him the only consolation he can receive in his last moments?

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: You do not surely advise me to it.

sp.speaker: Fash.
sp.p: From my soul I do—Dear Mrs. Fashion, said he, in faltering accents—Go to the unrelenting fair one, tell her, I die the victim of her obduracy—True, I was not worthy of aspiring to such excellence—But, if she will deign once more to look upon me, I'll implore her forgiveness, and, as a small atonement for my folly and presumption, request her acceptance of my fortune—That, though she could not love me living, she may compassionate my memory.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: His generosity affects me—I heartily with he may recover, but beg leave to decline his offer.

sp.speaker: Fash.
sp.p: Really, Miss, I did not think you could have been so ungratesul—What harm can there be in visiting a dying man?

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: I am abore suspecting any harm, but scorn to take advantage of his weakness for me.

sp.speaker: Fash.
sp.p: 'Tis no advantage—What do his friends value the few thousands he can bestow?—Come, I must persuade you to accept them.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Indeed, Mrs. Fashion, though I am far from being void of humanity, yet upon this occasion you must excuse me; you may assure him, that, if wisnes—

sp.speaker: Fash.
sp.p: No, no,—In all probability, he will not be alive in an hour's time—The very sight of you wou'd satisfy him, and then he would die contented.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: What shall I do?—

sp.speaker: Fash.
sp.p: Nay, don't hesitate at performing a charitable action.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Well, well—You have persuaded me.

sp.speaker: Fash.
sp.p: Ah, you are a sweet, good Lady, and I hope will be rewarded for your tenderness—Then, you promise to come immediately?

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: I do.

sp.speaker: Fash.
sp.p: Blessings on that complying countenance!—Could I but live to see you married to my wish, I should then be a happy woman!

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: So! so!—These eyes of mine will be brought in guilty of murder!—Well! I am certainly an unaccountable mortal—Though my heart feels the most delicate touches of sensibility, yet, this love of admiration hurries me, unthinkingly, into a thousand errors—Positively, I will reform—Ay, but how?—Why, marry—Oh, lud, the cure would be worse than the disease—And yet, was Sedley my doctor, I think he cou'd qualify the bitter portion—In short, I'm absolutely determined—on—what? To be as good as I can.

div3.head: SCENE, Lady YOUNGLOVE'S.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: Talk not of danger, my sweet girl! who could be separated from you so long, and not purchase such precious moments at any risque?

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: O dear! what a bounce my heart gave when I saw you—I'm frightened out of my wits at your rashness—If my Mamma catches us, we are undone for ever.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: You need not fear, Miss, your Mamma's in too great a concatenation herself, tomind you; and she has sent all the servants out, about one fribalous thing, or other—However, to make sure, I'll stand centry myself for you, so make good use of your time, you young rogues.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p:
My impatience would not let me wait the success of a scheme I had concerted with Sedley, this
morning; I was resolved to see you, so made use of my key of the gate at the end of the lane, to let myself into the garden, from whence I slipt up the back stairs.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: You are too venturesome, yet, I'm glad you are come to my relief—My Mamma insists positively upon my marrying your Uncle to-night.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: I know it, my angel, but we will disappoint her, if you'll consent to let me convey you to a place where we may be united beyond the power of separation.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: I would run any hazard to avoid so hateful a union—And, yet, Woodford, should you behave unkindly to me, when I'm under your protection, it would break my heart.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: He must be a villain indeed, who could wrong such innocence—No, rely upon my truth and honour—Let me but lead you from hence, now we have this favourable opportunity, and before we are missed, I hope we shall be far enough out of the reach of a pursuit.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: With all my heart—For, to confess the truth, I should like to be run away with into Scotland above all things—O lud! it will be so pleasant, so spirited, so fashionable, and make such a noise in the world!—Why, 'tis the very thing I have been wishing for, ever since I thought of marriage.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: I am happy to find you so readily approve of it.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p:
O dear! there is nothing gives a girl the air of consequence an elopement does—To have one's name bandied about in all the newspapers in the kingdom, with "We hear, that yesterday morning, the only daughter of Lady Younglove eloped with a young gentleman of family, and great expectations—They were immediately pursued by the young Lady's relations, out in vain—The guardian powers of love and beauty had taken them under their
protection—Phaeton lent them his chariot, Cupid was the winged Charioteer, and Hymen on the opposite banks of the Tweed, with open arms, welcomed them into the dominions of joy and happiness!"

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: My charming girl!—How your words animate me—I hope the event will prove equal to our most sanguine expectations—But, let us not waste the precious moments—Come, and—

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Stay, stay, not so hasty—Let me descend a little from my heroics to the level of common sense—Stop here a few moments, while I just step up stairs for some of my best cloaths.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: No, no, my dear, we shall have no occasion for them.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Ah, but I'm afraid we shall tho'—And if I can slip into my mamma's closet, I'll steal some of her jewels out.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: Not for the world—You are the only jewel I wish to possess—Let us deal honourably, and trust to her generosity for the future.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Then I'm afraid you'll trust to a broken reed.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: No matter, my love, we will put it to the test—I am sensible of the great hazard we both run by this precipitate step, which nothing, but the fear of losing you for ever, could urge me to—You, perhaps, have not considered it so seriously.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Why no, truly, I seldom consider about the matter—Reflection I know, will come time enough afterwards.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: Then can you, my rose-bud, in case your mamma is not reconciled to us, relinquish all hopes of a coach, with every other attendant on polite life, and be content to live in a cottage with love and me?

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p:
I must own, that I should like a coach prodigiously, but then I like you better—And if grandeur is only to be purchased at the expence of happiness,
a sig for it, and every other fine thing—Do you continue but to love me, and I shall be as happy as the day is long.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: My generous girl! whilst I have life, it shall be my study ro repay such obligations—Come, let us go down the back stairs, and proceed to Sedley's, where I have a chaise waiting for us.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Oh, undone! undone!—Here's your uncle, Sir Whiffling Trifle, and a French gentleman along with him, coming up stairs.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: Zounds! how unfortunate!

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Oh, quite misfortunate indeed!

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: O, dear! what will become of us?

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: Is there no place to hide me in?

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: O none, Sir, except you creep up the chimney, and so on to the top of the next house.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: Well, I am resolved—Frippery, leave the room directly.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Yes, Sir, O lud, O lud!

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: Don't be alarmed, my dear,—follow me, and fear nothing.

sp.stage: Enter Sir WHIFFLING, speaking to FINESSE.
sp.p: So, Monsieur Finesse, you really think my Museum contains more curiosities than—Hey, Mr. Woodford! in the name of all that's wonderful, what brought you here?

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: A design, Sir Whiffling, which your coming has unluckily interrupted, though not prevented—Let me beg of you therefore, to entertain Monsieur Finesse with the remainder of your invaluable curiosities, while I attend your niece down stairs.

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: I am astonished!—Hold, hold, Sir! you may go when, and where you please, but my niece shall not stir.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: You see, Sir Whiffling, all resistance is in vain.

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: Help! murder! help!

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: Not so loud, as you value your life.

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: For pity's sake, Monsieur, draw and assist me.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Pardonnez moy, Monsieur, I beg to be excuse.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: Lookee, Sir Whiffling, if you offer to molest me before I'm down stairs, and out of doors, the consequences may be fatal—Remember that caution as you regard your safety.

div3.stage: After they have stood some time looking at each other.

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: Do you think they are down stairs yet?

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: No, Monsieur, wait a leatle bit longer.

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: Draw your sword, and see if they be gone.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: To oblige you, I vill draw my sword, but, je vous demande pardon, I have more politesse dan to go before in your own house.

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: Hush!—I believe we may venture now—Come, follow me then.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Oui, Monsieur, I shall take de great care not to go first.

div3.head: SCENE Mrs. FASHION'S.
div3.stage: Enter Miss BLOOMER, and Mrs. FASHION.

sp.speaker: Fash.
sp.p: My dear Lady, I have impatiently expected you.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: How does his Lordship?

sp.speaker: Fash.
sp.p: Just alive, that's all.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Then there's no occasion for my disturbing him.

sp.speaker: Fash.
sp.p: The greatest in the world—He cannot die in peace till he has seen you.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: I wish our interview was over—You'll be sure to stay all the time in the room with me.

sp.speaker: Fash.
sp.p: Certainly—Nay, don't hesitate but let me lead you to him.

head.stage: SCENE changes, discovers a room darkened. FLAMWELL lying on a couch.

div3.stage: Enter Mrs. FASHION, and Miss BLOOMER.

sp.speaker: Fash
sp.p: My Lord!—My Lord!—'Tis all over—My Lord!

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Oh!—disturb me not—let me expire in quiet—'Tis not my charmer's voice.

sp.speaker: Fash.
sp.p: Still raving on you.—My sweet Lord, compose yourself—I have brought Miss Bloomer to take a last farewell.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: I am very faint—Ah, Madam, would I had strength to thank you for this favour!

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Be composed, my Lord—I am heartily sorry for your misfortune, and that I was the innocent occasion of it.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: I bless the hour, since it has procured me this satisfaction—I am weak with the loss of blood—Might I intreat you to come a little nearer—

sp.speaker: Fash.
sp.p: Do, my dear Miss Bloomer, sit down here—His Lordship cannot speak loud.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: I have but few moments to spare—On that table, Madam, lies my will, properly attested—In it you will find the respect I have entertained for you.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Pray, my Lord, excuse me, and give it to those who better deserve it.

sp.speaker: Fash.
sp.p: By my faith, he will not, so no more words.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: I have but one request to make, and then—I die composed.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Name it, my Lord,

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: That you might be legally mine, and—

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: My lord!

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: And after my death, without interruption, quietly to enjoy my title as well as fortune.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: I am greatly obliged to your Lordship, but give me leave positively, to decline both.

sp.speaker: Fash.
sp.p: Nay, now, Miss Bloomer, I really think you are very wrong—Consider, what an advantage it will be to you.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: I despise advantages obtained in such a manner.

sp.speaker: Fash.
sp.p: Indeed, you are too delicate—It will be a public and honourable testimony of his love and gratitude.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: I desire no such testimonies, and, if that was your design, you'll find you've lost your aim.

sp.speaker: Fash.
sp.p: Can you refuse such a trifling, momentary satisfaction to a man who is just leaving the world?

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Can you be so inhuman, to load a man just leaving the world, with such a weight as matrimony?

sp.speaker: Fash.
sp.p: Come, all this is feigned—You must and shall be Lady Flamwell—the Chaplain is waiting without—I'll call him in, and he'll soon run over the words—Here, Mr. Ty'em,—walk in, walk in!

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Mrs. Fashion!—Stay!—What do you mean by using me thus?—I'll leave your house instantly.

sp.speaker: Ty'em.
sp.p: Are the parties ready?

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: No, Sir—Have a care what you are about—If you dare proceed a step further in this affair, you shall be made a public example of.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: My gentle Lady, can you suffer me to die in despair?

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: My ungentle Lord! I am not to be trick'd in this manner—Cease your idle solicitations.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: Not but with my life—Your cruelty has given me new vigor (Rising from his couch) And thus I seize my happiness.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Hold off!—What! have I been deceiv'd!—ensnar'd!—'Tis plain—Villain!—who are you?

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: A man, Madam, who is resolved to make a proper use of this advantage—Come, Madam, you have no time for deliberation—Either this moment let me make you honourably mine, or—necessity will compel me to make use of force to oblige you.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Monster! I detest you, and despise your threats!—Dare not for your life, Sir, to bar my way.

sp.speaker: Ty'em.
sp.p: Verily, you are righteously joined together, and I am ready to affirm, that the ceremony is performed.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: How am I beset!

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: You must comply—There is no possibility of escaping.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Help! murder! help!

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: 'Tis all in vain.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Help! help! for heaven's sake!

div3.stage: Door broke open—Enter SEDLEY, WOODFORD, CONSTABLE, and SERVANTS. They secure FLAMWELL and TY'EM.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Hold, miscreants! or this moment is your last.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: Look to the Lady, she faints—

sp.speaker: Confr.
sp.p: Look to the gentleman here, first—He seems to be in the worst condition.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p:
What a scene of horror!—Dear Woodford,
do you secure that wicked woman without, while I assist Miss Bloomer.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: I will, and as I shall take your advice in restoring Flora to her mother, will leave Mrs. Fashion in the hands of these worthy gentlemen, and wait at your house for your return.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: O, Sedley! is it to you that I am indebted for this providential rescue?—'Tis doubly, doubly welcome.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: I am sorry, Madam, that I cannot return the compliment—Mr. Constable, conduct these villains to your own house, till they are properly examined.

sp.speaker: Con.
sp.p: Yes, Sir—Come along, my lads, don't be so down-hearted—You are not so bad now as you will be, that's some comfort—The gallows, you know, never can come out of season to you, and so, better late than never.

sp.speaker: Flam.
sp.p: O, my curst fortune!—Yes, now I see I shall cut a distinguishing figure in the world!

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: When we last parted, Miss Bloomer, little did I expect we should have met in such a manner—Give me leave to ask, what am I to judge from your appearance here?

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: The truth—that I was innocently decoyed here, by the wicked woman who keeps this house.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Fain, fain would I believe so, did not other parts of your conduct contradict it.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: My conduct, Sir, though faulty in this particular, is in every other respect irreproachable.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: I should be happy indeed, Madam, if you could prove it.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Surprizing!—What right have you, Sir, to call my actions in question?

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: None, Madam, none—The busy world has done it for you.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Know, Sir, I rely on my own integrity, and despise what you or the world can say of me.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: It too plainly appears, Madam, that you have not the least regard for either.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Good heavens! but I will be calm—I see your artifice, you poorly seek an excuse for your own inconstancy—The oaths, the vows, the sighs you so long offered up to me, are now transferred to a more amiable, and deserving object—Lady Younglove, Sir, has sent me an invitation of the kindest nature—

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: I know it, Madam—Too long have I dangled in the train of a Coquette, but I am at last convinced, that the levity of your conduct, forbids me ever to hope the least happiness, with a woman of your gaiety.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Burst, burst, swelling bosom, ere I give you vent. (aside) O, Sir, you are convinced at last—'Tis very well, Sir,—I am satisfied—perfectly satisfied—Then you give me up for ever.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: For ever, Madam, by heaven!

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Cruel, ungenerous, Sedley!—What have I done to deserve this insult?—especially from you, who of all men, I am least able to bear it from.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Tears! my heart can hold no longer—Madam, Miss Bloomer!—Heaven is my witness, I bleed to wound you thus—I love you! I adore you!—Had I millions they should be yours—But, what can I say?—Thus circumstanced, I am compelled, dear as I love, to bid you eternally farewell—Yet, though I am wretched, compleatly wretched, may the guardian powers of love and innocence, wait on your footsteps, shadow you with their wings, and conduct you to that happiness you have deprived me of.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p:
Stay, rash man, stay—My pride forbids
me to stoop to a vindication—Yet, my weakness confesses, that had it not been for your present behaviour, I should have preferred you before all the men I ever saw—'Till this moment I knew not half the power you had over me—Yes, cruel Sedley, enjoy that triumph, but at the same time know, I will, if possible, tear your image from my breast, and bury myself where I may never hear your name mentioned.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Hold, my charming angel!—By heaven you shall not go—Thus on my knees (Kneeling) let me intreat for pardon—Forgive the man, who doats on you to distraction, who lives but in your smiles—Abhorred be my tongue for thus wantonly wounding your sensibility, and uttering what my heart disclaims.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: I am astonished!—And, are you really not engaged to Lady Younglove?

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: By all the powers of love, I am not, nor ever will be—'Twas all an artifice, to serve my friend, and try the strength of your affection—If you refuse my hand, never shall it be the lifeless property of another.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Generous man! I am not worthy of you!—No, Sedley, virtues like yours deserve infinitely more than I am able to bestow.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Say not so, my beauteous girl!—You must, you shall be mine—My happiness is centered in you—Blest be the fortunate accident that thus luckily revealed I was not indifferent to you.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p:
And doubly blest let it be, since it has opened my eyes, and shewn me the glaring impropriety of my former conduct—What a dreadful precipice have I escaped!—How have I—But, my future life best shall speak my sense of the past—Here let me seriously renounce all former follies—Never from this hour, will I be guilty of them—You have at last effectually compleated the arduous
task you so long pursued—REFORMED A COQUETTE—And now, if you dare—take her for your pains.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: O transport inexprssible!—Am I at last rewarded!

sp.speaker: Miss Belg.
sp.p: Hey-day! may I believe my eyes!—Here's a change indeed!—Embraching!

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: O, my dear girl! I am glad you are come.

sp.speaker: Miss Belg.
sp.p: Really, so am I.—Your humble servant, Mr. Proteus, I am pleased to find you in such spirits—Not an hour ago, you was the resolute determined hero—No, no, Madam, I can love without being blind.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: True, Madam, and without being entirely so; where could I six, but on so deserving an object? You seem surprized: let us adjourn to Lady Younglove's, and in our way thither, I'll let you into my whole design.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Here, take my hand—My heart has not been so much at ease a long time—And, if girls were but wise enough to consult their own happiness, instead of their trisling with fools and coxcombs, they would seek for it where it can only be found—In the arms of men of sense, and virtue.

div3.head: SCENE, Lady YOUNGLOVE'S.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: UPON my word, Miss, this is the most oddest affair I was ever extricated in during the whole current of my life—After getting so artificially off as you did, for Mr. Sedley to dissuade your lovyer to return you to your mamma again, instead of flourishing away to Scotland without redemption—Well! I own its above my compacity to find out.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Ay, or mine either—I'm sure, I never looked so foolish in all my life, as when I found we were not to be married.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: And well you might, Miss, to have all your schemes confisticated in such a manner.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: And then, Frippery, to be disappointed of such a delightful jaunt, and exposed to the ridicule of all one's acquaintance—'Tis, enough to make me cry my eyes out.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Ay, my dear, so it is—And, pray, what end did he impose by this wise scheme?

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Why, as by such a precipitate step we should entirely forfeit the favour of his uncle, and my mamma, without the least chance of recovery, he persuaded Woodford to wait the issue of a scheme which he is going to execute immediately—For my part, if it does succeed, I shall lose half the pleasure I expected in being married in Scotland.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p:
You are right, Miss, and speak the sensations of most of the girls who go there—Why, I might have been married three years ago to Mr. Scraper, Lord Supple's footman, but that we could not raise
money enough between us to get there, and I was determined never to follow the vulgar fashion, of being asked in church.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: So, my pretty runaway Miss! I have you safe once more, thanks to Mr. Sedley, and shall take care to keep you so.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Perhaps you may be mistaken (aside) It is mighty well, mamma, but you would not like to be served so yourself.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Go, hussey, you are a pert spoiled girl—Now, Frippery, after this last generous act of Mr. Sedley's, I think, I can't have the least doubt of his sincerity, truth, and tenderness.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Doubt, Madam! it would be downright fidelity even to inspect him of such a thing.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: How tediously the lazy minutes drawl, to a heart impatient of its bliss like mine!—Frippery, do you think I am elegantly enough dressed for my bridal day?

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: Elegant, my Lady!—Why, you are the very moral of gentility—Your new cork-rump becomes you mightily—And Mr. Friz, the hair-dresser, says, that your head is now at least half a foot higher than the handsome Duchess's.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: I am glad of it—O, the dear, sweet man!—He promised to be here about this time—I wish he was come—My patience is almost exhausted, and I tremble left any accident should rob me of my expected happiness.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: If she should be disappointed now.

sp.speaker: Frip.
sp.p: I warrant your Ladyship need not fear—No, no, Mr. Sedley is too much of a gentleman to refuse you any thing.

div3.stage: Enter SEDLEY, Captain HELM, Miss BLOOMER, WOODFORD, and SWAB.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: My beauteous widow!

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: My long expected love!

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: I wish my mamma would not be quite so fond before company.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: My dear Lady, I have been obliged to trespass on your patience, in order to bring these witnesses of my happiness.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Ay, ay, widow, we have crowded all the sail we could to be in at the first broadside, and now, as we all seem in the line, suppose we hoist the signal for engaging?

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: With all my heart, Captain, the sooner, the better.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Bravely spoken, and I'll answer, that you'll not be the first to cry out quarter.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Oh, Miss Bloomer! I am happy to see you—My dear, this is an unexpected favour—Well, now, after your known partiality for Sedley, can you forgive his infidelity to you?—I protest it gives me pain to rob you of such a sweet man.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Your Ladyship is too good—I should be vain indeed, were I to pretend to dispute a heart with one of your Ladyship's age and experience.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! very pleasant—And yet, I really wonder, what the men can see in me so to follow and admire—Especially, when they sacrifice such youth and beauty—But, I hope no bad consequences will follow your disappointment—No hanging, or drowning—O lud! I positively will give up all thoughts of him, sooner than be the death of any person.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: What a malicious devil. (aside) I hope, Madam, I have now removed every shadow of doubt which your Ladyship might have entertained of my sincerity.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p:
Entirely, Sir, entirely—And, in order to convince the world of my disinterested love for so deserving an object—Previous to the ceremony, which is to make me happy for ever—there
is a deed of gift— (Presenting it to Sedley)—properly attested, of half my fortune at present, and, the other half at my death.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: My dear Lady, what can I say to such unbounded, such unmerited proofs of your goodness?

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Say! zounds, man, say nothing—The widow had rather be thanked in deed than in word.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: I am afraid, Captain, it is not in my power to please the Lady either way.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: O fie, Mr. Sedley, don't think so—I assure you I am not the unreasonable woman you take me for.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: I am glad of it, Madam, as I must speedily put you to the trial.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: I think, Sir, I can stand any trial you'll please to make.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: I wish we may find it so, Madam—By your misplaced, and with justice I may say, ridiculous inclination, my Lady, for I cannot call it love, you have been so far blindly infatuated, as to make me sole master of your fortune without reserve—

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: How!—Am I awake?

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Faith, I believe not—But, there seems a storm rising that will quickly call all hands to work.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Well! I declare this is charming!

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: I am above making an improper use of such an advantage—I designed at first, but to serve my friend, and now my end is fully answered—Give me leave therefore, in the presence of this good company, to restore these writings to their just owner.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Oh, I shall faint! this is too much, too much to bear!

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Poor mamma! So, it is indeed, to lose both money and husband—Sir, I have not words to thank you as I ought.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Am I betrayed then!—You base deluder! villain!

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha! I hope your Ladyship will forgive his infidelity to you—I protest it gives me pain to rob you of such a sweet man.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Confusion! are all my ravishing dreams of happiness come to this!—Oh, the inconstancy of mankind! there's neither love, faith, truth, or honour amongst them.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: But, I hope, no bad consquences will follow your disappointment—No hanging, or drowning—O lud! I positively will give up all thoughts of him, sooner than be the death of any person.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Come, my Lady, forgive this innocent artifice, and look upon me as your best friend—You might have fallen a dupe to some designing villain—who, taking advantage of your weakness, would have ruined your family, and entailed perpetual misery on yourself.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: So! we are all run on a lee shore, here!—Why, widow, you have kept a devilish bad reckoning—But I thought how it would be—As for your generosity, Mr. Sedley, in favour of my little cockboat, why, I heartily thank you—And, as soon as the parson can tip us a cocket, we'll steer away for matrimony harbour, directly.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: I'm afraid, Captain, wind and tide are so much against you, that you'll hardly be able to reach the port this trip.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: How's this!—Do you refuse to take convoy too?

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: No, provided I chuse my confort—I'm sure, if I kept company with you, I should soon be obliged to take you in tow.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Whew! (whistling) Here's a fresh gale sprung up!

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: I think, Captain, you have kept a bad reckoning.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p:
And now, Woodford, thanks to Mr. Sedley's
generosity, I have it in my power to manifest my love—Here, take my hand, my fortune's more than sufficient to enable us to live happily, though not splendidly—But, were it not, be assured, I would chearfully prefer poverty and a cottage, with the object of my choice, before riches and the most splendid palace with the man I dislike.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Right, Madam, the temple of Hymen was reared by virtue, and only occasionally embellished by Plutus.—Captain, I am sure, if you seriously consider every thing, you will soon be of the young Lady's mind.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: May-hap not, for when I am resolved on doing any thing, I never think about the matter.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: Dear uncle, make my happiness complete by restoring me to your favour—Recollect what a cruel constraint you were putting upon both our inclinations.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: And, you young dog, do you recollect what a cruel constraint you are putting upon mine?

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: I know, Captain, you are a noble-spirited, worthy-hearted Briton—Only reflect, with such a great disparity of years and temper, what a ridiculous figure you must make united to so blooming a girl.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: Ay, for all the world, like David and Abishag, in our old tapestry hangings.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Come, be generous, and act like yourself—Fill up the marriage settlements with your nephew's name, instead of your own, and receive the thanks, nay, the blessings of the young couple, for so laudable an act.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: Upon my knees, uncle, let me beg—

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Rise, you land spaniel—When did you ever see a seaman in such a posture?—Had it been for a brother tar, why, I should not have held council about it.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Well! it is some comfort, to find others in the same situation with myself.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: So! after rigging myself out for a cruize to the unknown islands, my orders are countermanded, I am to be dock'd, and laid up for life, as unfit for service.

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: Why, an please your honour, I do think your works are too much damaged, to venture out to sea again—You'd certainly founder in the first storm.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Do you think so, Swab?—Then let us tack about, and alter our course—Come hither, nephew, I forgive you what's past—You shall go master in my stead, and here are bills of freight and lading for the voyage—But, harkee, as you are a young seaman, take my advice—Don't crowd too much sail, or you'll be apt to overset.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: Never fear, uncle, I'll steer by your direction—your goodness to me on this occasion—

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: No fair-weather speeches, but mind your business—And, d'ye hear, boy, by way of encouragement to serve his Majesty, you shall have a thousand pounds bounty money for every young volunteer you produce, as soon as ever they are able to cry, Huzza! King George and his navy for ever—Ay, damme! tho' you should have above the royal dozen!

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: There spoke the true spirit of a British seaman.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: What say you. Widow?—As we both have been a couple of ridiculous old fools, to make amends, will you join with me, and do the same?

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Do the same, Captain?—I did not rightly understand you—You have not, surely, any notion of paying your addresses to me?

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: To you!—Avast there, sheer off——No, sooner than be tack'd to such a spit-fire, I'd turn a gun into my powder-room, and blow myself up.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: A monster!—A savage bear!—Fit only for Greenland!

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Well! a Greenland bear is better than a Lapland witch, at any time.

sp.speaker: Lady Young.
sp.p: Come along, Frippery—The men have neither eyes, ears, or understanding!

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Ay, ay, let her have sea-room enough, or she'll run foul of some of you.

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: Please your honour, since you are sharing the prize-money, I hope you'll not be angry if I put in my claim?

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: What wind blows now?

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: A fair gale, your honour; if I can but press yon painter tender into service.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Oh, are you in that quarter?—Have you a mind to desert your commander in distress?

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: No, your honour, never while I have life—, she seems a neat tight-sailing thing, and her upper works are in such nice order, that I should like, of all things, to go master.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: But, hearkee, have you hail'd her yet, to know whether she'd chuse to take you on board?

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: Why, no, your honour; I'm too good a seaman to launch out on so long a cruize without my commander's leave.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Well, then, Swab, if that's the case, after her directly, and bring her too as soon as possible.

sp.speaker: Swab.
sp.p: I warrant your honour; to give a good account of her—He must stand many a hard broadside that takes her from me.

div3.stage: Enter Miss BELCROVE, Sir WHIFLING, and SPANGLE.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Hey day! here's a Venetian galley, and a whole squadron of Turkish cruizers in full chace of her.

sp.speaker: Miss Bel.
sp.p: True, Captain, I have been oblig'd to ran for it, and glad to find this harbour open.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Say you so, then let me stand in—I'll soon make them tack about, and sheer off.

sp.speaker: Miss Bel.
sp.p: No occasion, Captain, I'll stand my ground now, and face them—Well, good folks, I see by those smiles that are seated on your countenances, that every thing is happily settled—I give you joy—I met these gentlemen in my way hither, they would not believe me, so are come to receive their dismission from your own lips.

sp.speaker: Span.
sp.p: Is this true, my dear girl, that you have the inhumanity to be the death of all my hopes?

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: And can you, Miss Bloomer, behold my sufferings without a touch of pity?

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: The time has been, gentlemen, when I could have play'd on your follies, and encouraged them with the highest pleasure—At present, I am disposed to be more serious—Therefore, in a word, I beg I may not be honoured with your addresses more, as you may rest assured, that I never will give you, or any others, the least encouragement.

sp.speaker: Span.
sp.p: And this, my dear, is your positive resolution?

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Positive.

sp.speaker: Span.
sp.p: Upon my soul, my dear, I am sorry for your taste—But to shew you how fashionably easy I am, under my disappointment—May elegance renounce me, if I ever ask you again—So, ladies and gentlement, wishing you all happiness, I have the honour, sans ceremonie, to remain, till my latest moments, your most devoted humble servant.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Ha! ha! ha!—As to you, Sir Whifling, I hope your philosophy will teach you to bear this event with equal resignation.

sp.speaker: Flora.
sp.p: O, I'll answer for my uncle——Give him another antedeluvian cockle-shell, and he'll renounce the sex for ever.

sp.speaker: Sir Whif.
sp.p: Not so pert, Miss—Madam, your frankness charms me—I begin to perceive that I deserve ridicule for the folly of my pursuits—But, to shew you, that, tho' I am old, I am not incorrigible, I'll from this moment bid adieu to all thoughts of love, and devote the remainder of my life to more noble studies than either brickbats, cinders, or mutilated statues.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: Now, Belgrove, are not these genuine fruits of reformation?

div3.stage: Enter FINESSE. [On seeing Sedley and Miss Bloomer, attempts to retire]

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Ha! Monsieur Finesse, come back—Why in such a hurry?

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Je demande pardon for my intrusion—You be upon de private business—Je revendrai demain, I'll come again to-morrow.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: No, Sir, the present time will do better—Hearkee, villain! what motive cou'd induce you to destroy my peace, by your infamous misrepresentations of Miss Bloomer?—No evasion, wretch! (drawing) or this moment shall be your last.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: O dear Sir! prenez garde!—Consider how soon you may frighten a pauvre Frenchman out of his wits.

sp.speaker: Miss Bloom.
sp.p: What, my admirer, Monsieur Finesse, is it to you I am so much indebted?

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Ah, Madame! have pitie!—I confesse, I have been von grand rogue—But, je vous en supplie—I beseech you to forgive me.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: Rise!—A moment's reflection shews me that you are a wretch beneath my resentment.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: I'l est vrai—It is true. indeed, Sir.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: Hearkee, suppose we tar and feather him, and then send him home to his own country, to parlez vous with his relations.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: By no means, Captain—But, hence from my sight, let me never see you more.

sp.speaker: Fin.
sp.p: Vous me faites trop d' honneur—You do me too much honour.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: The Frenchman, of character and probity, I admire and esteem—Virtue is not confin'd to clime or complexion, its radient emanations illumine every nation—Yet still, I would not fashionably encourage the resuse of foreign countries, while native merit lies buried in oblivion.

sp.speaker: Miss Bel.
sp.p: So, Captain, you and I seem the only disconsolate, unprovided creatures in the whole group—We certainly should make a match of it, to complete the evening's entertainment.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: No, no, fair Lady, you have some other land in view—As for me—But, no more of what's past—Let us enjoy the present moments.

sp.speaker: Woodf.
sp.p: And look forward, uncle, to those scenes of bliss which open to our view.

sp.speaker: Helm.
sp.p: True, Boy, and as this seems but a bad harbour to anchor long in, let us all steer away for my cabin, where you shall have the best cheer an old bachelor can give, and as hearty a welcome as the bravest sailor in the navy.

sp.speaker: Sedley.
sp.p: We accept your offer, Captain, happy in having our adventures brought to so agreeable a conclusion—I only beg leave to remark—That though our follies and vices justly deserve the comic lash—Yet, when, instead of persevering, we nobly acknowledge our errors, and amend—Satire then loses her sting, our foibles turn to virtues, and, the most permanent felicity arises from THE MISTAKES OF THE HEART.
